bookDescription:
Both Ben and Keep are surprised when a desperate shipping magnate shows up on Atlas hoping for an audience. His business is failing, and he's convinced of foul play. Keep thinks it's a run of bad luck. Ben isn't so sure.
Before long, Ben's chasing saboteurs who shouldn't exist, investigating crimes that make no sense, and trying to stop a war between the Empire and the Outer Rim. Oh, and Emerald keeps insisting they're married.
The clock is ticking as Ben and his crew race to figure out who's responsible for the madness before businesses collapse, people die, and Emerald actually makes Ben go to couple's therapy. But when every lead points in a different direction and even his allies can't be trusted, Ben's going to learn that the deck has been stacked from the beginning.
Good thing he's always been a wild card.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Ben & company face their toughest challenge to date. At least they get a little bit of information about the Carapal. Its last occupant was a master of chaos energy. And Ben has to go head-to-head against him. At least Emerald gets a new bestie.

bookDescription: Book 1 in the Scouring SeriesAs the Siege of Terra ends, there are many loose ends – Traitors trying desperately to escape, a monumental vacuum of power to fill, and a crumbling galactic government to see to. Those who hold on to power must decide how to wield it, and a new structure must be put in place, all while desires to exact vengeance run high.READ IT BECAUSEIt's the beginning of an epic series. Find out what happens after the cataclysmic events of the Horus Heresy, as an unsteady Imperium must find its footing and learn how to exist without the guidance of the Emperor.THE STORYHorus is dead. Terra lies in ruins. The Emperor is silent. Amid the rubble of the Palace, shell-shocked survivors emerge into the light of an uncertain dawn. New powers are present now, ones that have travelled the length of the galaxy to bring salvation to the Imperium, though they are as readily cast as usurpers as redeemers. The survivors of the Traitors’ Grand Armada, now scattered and desperate to escape vengeance, are riven with doubt and dissension, and their gods too are silent. Amid all the grief and confusion, some hopeful souls believe the war to be over and an era of renewal just ahead. But wiser heads know that this war can never end, and that the only question remaining is who shall rise to power within the perilous new age, and who shall fall.Written by Chris Wraight.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: The Heresy is done, and the aftermath is all around us.This is a quiet book, a very different book. There's still warfare all around of course, and plenty of killing, but we get to see the damage done to the soul of Mankind.Everybody has been hurt. The Emperor, the Primarchs, the loyalists, the Traitors, the Gods themselves have been hurt. Everybody is in pain now, and all they know is to lash out at each other.This is the connective tissue that binds the Horus Heresy to 40K, this is the most thorough straightline you will see as 30K becomes 40K properly, and everything clicks into place.

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: A deeply mixed bag with more bad than good...*SPOILERS*
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: *SPOILER WARNING*First off, do not be fooled by the cover art. The book does feature a council of the Primarchs, and the High Lords of Terra, but it is astonishingly brief and does nothing but degrade the sensibilities of beloved characters. It would seem, to my mind, beyond certain that the loyalist sons would have the good sense - after a ruinous war of Heresy caused by their once-brother - not to argue and snipe with one another in front of the rest of the Imperial leaders when the dust had barely settled and the blood not yet dried. This is overestimating them, apparently.Despite neither the Siege of Terra V3 and Era of Ruin not featuring it - and it being arguably an incredibly important piece of lore for the reader to see and understand - AotI does not include a solo meeting/reunion of the Primarchs in the immediate aftermath of Horus' defeat. Nor does it feature any Primarch POV chapters. We do not get to see them collectively grieve, nor resolutely unite, after their Lord Father's gruesome downfall. This is a big misstep, in my opinion.On top of the omissions, the staggering bloat in this book, and sheer pointlessness of some of the subplots (I can't fathom why they included a Chaos Cultist's pointless flight across barren Terran plains in lieu of a Blood Angels POV about their fallen Lord), is matched only by the baffling fixation on minutia. There are parts of it that are about as thrilling to read as a cargo manifesto. Did any of the Black Library authors think that's what people who have stuck with the franchise for decades wanted to read about in such a rich and storied setting? This series is arguably more interesting than the Siege was, and yet they waste so much of its potential.Speaking of omissions; there are no Abaddon chapters, nothing whatsoever featuring Corax (bar a brief reference to his seat at the council being empty), nothing whatsoever about the White Scars except a brief appearance by their Primarch, nothing concerning Valdor that isn't just a passing comment, and nothing of note happens in respect of the Mechanicus/Mechanicum (no POV chapters). Worst of all, in my view, we don't get to read the perspective of any of the Ultramarines as they first landed on Terra to help lift the siege.All that being said; this book was clearly written with purpose. It is abundantly clear that Wraight has created a through-line between The Scouring and the current 40K timeline in that Guilliman is, for baffling reasons that might be why they've delayed his union with El'Jonson for so long, being set up as an Empire-stealing maniac whose actions might spark a civil war.It also seems, in my view at least, to have been purposely crafted with just enough hints and bread-crumbs about larger in-universe implications to get LoreTubers churning out endless content about it over one single line of text.With those considerations in mind; it is a well-written book, and it does move the 30K timeline forward slightly. It is just, perhaps, one only for the purist collectors and setting enthusiasts. In my opinion, it does not provide enough substance to justify the price.Bought on Kindle.
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on December 6, 2025

bookDescription: High in earth orbit, the Fist of Orion has been busy.With new Shrike attack craft, Van decides it's time to go on the offensive. Despite bringing peace to many of the stars, the war has turned—and come home, bringing with it a new kind fight that Van knows all to well.Politics.With that brawl comes money, and with money, the fight gets serious. Retta's network reveals a threat rising in Europe, as various nations struggle to break free of earth, make bonds among the stars, and find new and exciting ways to turn the planet into something to be packaged and sold.For a profit, of course.Earth isn't the only world in danger, and a mystery in deepest space brings a strange connection to Perry's past—one that will unlock a second front on Van's war, all while opening the crew up to danger rooted in the halls of Anvil Dark.Anvil Dark, and the GKU aren't allies, not really, and Van is faced with old enemies and new recruits in a dirty fight for control of something that should belong to everyone—the law. Using technocrats, criminals, and opportunists, Van's enemies have bought their way into an alliance that will push the Fafnir and her crew into a battle for the ultimate control of earth's future——And the defense of earth will be waged as Van keeps one eye on deepest space, where an ancient enemy has awakened, eager for vengeance. Eager for the end of all life.And eager to end the Tudor line, once and for all.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Satisfying, if somewhat unoriginal conclusion to latest story arc
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I have read all the books in this series  (hard to believe this is No 30) and was pretty happy with how it played out, although ending borrows pretty heavily from some plot twists in the last good Star Trek movie, The Undiscovered Country, and uses some other well worn plot devices.  Chaney has a habit of doing that.After a couple of false starts with this story arc, which began with the orginal crew's adult kids being shoved to the forefront (not very interesting), things are back on track here.  Thankfully, Van, Torina, Perry,  Icky, Funboy and freinds are (mostly)  in charge for this big finale.  Which involves bad guys from the earliest books of the series.  Still, it is clear the series will continue, since there is a setup for new story arc at the very end.

bookDescription:
Peace lasted exactly seventeen days.
David Wayne just wanted to build mechs. His breakthrough changed everything: a partnership between human creativity and AI processing that makes him unstoppable in combat.
It also made him the most hunted man in the solar system.
The attacks come from everywhere. Golden statues that cost more than colonies. Shell companies that bleed millions through legal warfare. Encrypted signals that whisper of something called Chimera. Behind it all, someone orchestrates a symphony of pressure designed to break him or bend him to their will.
When his mentor's technology gets twisted into something monstrous, David realizes the truth: they don't want to destroy him. They want to become him. Someone is building an army based on his blueprint, turning his revolutionary partnership into a tool for mass control.
Seven lives hang in a cosmic storm. One impossible rescue. Zero room for error.
The choice that saves them might doom everyone else.
How far will David go to protect his creation from becoming humanity's greatest threat? Will his decision save the galaxy or unleash something that should never exist?
Dive into this adrenaline-fueled military thriller where innovation becomes the ultimate weapon.

bookDescription: A galactic powder keg explodes...And one small ship is at the center of it all.With Earth wiped out, and half her crew gone, the UES Interchange limps toward Sirius - the Dog Star, which aliens call the Beacon.There, Captain Seemey, Sergeant Morgan, and the remnants of their crew are pulled into what promises to be the war to end all wars.A dark force has all but taken over, and galactic powers are fighting over what's left.If the Interchange's crew can't ignite the spark that finally gives the Enemy pause - even as they contend with what has already been done to them - then all will be lost.Download I, Starship: That Which Ignites now and grab the edge of your seat for this bold new space opera.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Surely, it can't get any worse than this, right?
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This 6th chapter in the I, Starship series of novels continues the excellent character development of Sgt. Henry Morgan.  Capt. Seemey has evolved from a pompous ass to a proper starship captain who willingly accepts and depends on Henry for survival of the UES Interchange.  As they struggle to unite the various surviving factions, a new and infinitely more dangerous foe approaches.  I read this book over the weekend, and couldn't put it down!  This is the perfect setup for the next book.  I know this book (6) just came out, but I'm so excited to read book 7, I'm starting to vibrate.  You must release book 7 now, before I destroy the fabric of time!

bookDescription: Master Sergeant Gant Maker was a highly-decorated and well-respected Marine - until his last mission left him as the sole survivor of an encounter with a vicious race called the Vacra. Served up as a scapegoat and drummed out of the military, he has since lived a life of seclusion with only an adopted alien as a companion.Now the Vacra have returned. As the only person to have ever faced them and survived, Maker is reinstated in the Corps and given the onerous task of finding this enemy on a world located at the edge of known space. Assisting him is an unlikely band of military rejects, including a blind sharpshooter, an unstable psychic, and a genetically-engineered killing machine who refuses to fight.Given that the Vacra have superior weapons and technology, Maker recognizes that his team is at a distinct disadvantage. But Marines are nothing if not resourceful, and Maker has an audacious plan that just may level the playing field – if it doesn’t get them all killed.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Unorthodox in a very good way.
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Heinlien’s “Starship Troopers” was published  65 years ago and thus was born the genre.  You would think after that long plots would start to get repetitive, but people like Kevin Hardman are keeping it alive and well with superbly crafted plots and exquisite character development.  Worth every word and page.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: I enjoyed this: good military sci-fi
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Not earthshaking writing, but great plot, aliens, marines, enemies, and action.  A fun afternoon and good enough that I bought the next book and will start reading after I close this off.  There is a lot of awesome character development potential here, and I hope this story is just the beginning of an excellent series.This is the first and only book I've read by Kevin Hardman, so far.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on July 22, 2019

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Great read, looks to be a good series
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Terminus: Fringe Worlds #1, my tenth read/listen from author Kevin Hardman & the first book in a series that looks to be excellent! I don't restrict my reading to any particular genre. Instead, I'm a sucker for anything with memorable characters & a story that keeps me on the edge of my seat until the end. Reminiscent of Michael Anderle & Sarah Noffke’s Ghost Squadron series and Isaac Hooke’s Forever Gate series. Narrator Mikael Naramore’s talented narration added greatly to the book’s enjoyment. I was given an Audible copy of this book & am voluntarily reviewing it. Since I own both the Kindle & Audible edition I was able to follow along while being read to. I have to admit there were times I sped up the book because I couldn't wait to see what happened next. Different than his Kid Sensation series I’ll be reading more from this author & look forward to the rest of the series! (RIP Marley January 20, 2014 - July 24, 2018).
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2019

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Great action, fun characters, great story!!
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Surprisingly imaginative.  Nicely written light sci-fi with balanced action and dialogue.  Author knows how to tell a story with (for sci-fi genre) believable characters.  Best of all, no lengthy philosophy or huge sections of prose.  Really enjoyed the story.  Great example of archetype of disgraced leader / rag-tag group.  I liked all the team members so well, I’d read a book with any of them in the lead, especially Tinker or Fierce and Scope.

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: Interesting story...although not enough to purchase a sequel

This story is very much character centric and the characters are great. The main character Gant Maker is everything a good marine should be. The crew he gathers around him are all fab characters in their own right. There is plenty of action but we are not awash in details about armour and weapons, or explanations about how the tech works, which can get tedious. It’s just a good shoot ‘em up, blow ‘em up yarn. There is plenty of spacefaring aliens and humanities own ‘hub’ of planets. Again not bogged down in detail of how we got there. Just this is where we are not let’s have an adventure. I am looking forward to the next book.

Loved this book from start to finish, great action, even better characters you can relate too. The storyline was a winner from the start of the book, I loved Gants character and his Alien buddy, who was a mystery to start with,but you soon came to realize they rely on each other. Can't wait to read the next in the series, and a freebie to boot. Fab

bookDescription: When your starship's computer undergoes a catastrophic meltdown, light years from help, it's bad.When you are that ship's computer, it's worse.Fresh from the destruction of the colony they were assigned to protect, the UES Interchange is now hurtling toward Proxima Centauri, there to rally reinforcements against the tide of revolutionary rage currently rocking the galaxy.But when they arrive, they find the heart of galactic civilization eerily quiet...and empty. At the same time, Sergeant Henry Morgan, the ship's computer, is utterly unresponsive.The curtain is about to be pulled back on a secret so dark it will break the crew of the Interchange right down the middle.In its wake, the only question to answer will be whether their mission can continue at all.Download I, Starship: The Scattering Stars now and grab the edge of your seat for this bold new space opera.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: "The Scattering Stars", book 5 in the space opera series "I, Starship" by Scott Bartlett took me by surprise. The series so far is fast paced, full of battles, deceit, edge of your seat writing. I expected book 5 to continue on the same way. My reviews are usually long (check out the previous ones!). So, in order to not write about spoilers, I'll do a quick summary. Something changed, the tone was different. Yes, the characters were the same, and Scott Bartlett definitely followed his previous books. But I experienced an emotion I never had before. I cried. Anything beyond this description I think of being a spoiler. But this book, I feel, is the best so far in this series. Don't take my word for it. We all interpret books we read differently. Read it for yourself and I guarantee you will be waiting for book 6. It's just that good.

bookDescription: As a Marine, Henry Morgan would have said it was more likely he’d die from enemy fire than from being struck by a flying lawnmower while at a baseball game.But it was the lawnmower that ended up taking him out.A century later, Henry wakes up as a reconstituted intelligence, and is promptly drafted to be the governing AI for America’s first military starship. For one thing, as a reconstituted intelligence, he has no rights and can be forced to do the bidding of the powers that be. productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Transferring human consciousness into a computer to run a starship - what can go wrong?
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Ask yourself - what would you do if you could transfer your consciousness into a computer to live forever? Now imagine that your consciousness controls your new body - a state-of-the-art starship - what would you do now? What a great premise for a story. "I, Starship" is a story of just such a transfer of consciousness. Now image that your normal bodily functions like breathing, seeing, hearing, etc. are functions of the ship - air circulation systems, cameras throughout the ship (internal and external) that give you sight, microphones to allow you to hear everything that goes on in the ship, etc.  In addition, you control ship movement, both direction and speed. Oh, and not to forget the ships armament for protection from anything else you run into. What a super concept. Great story, great characters, and very interesting situations out in deep space. This is a wonderful read - go get this book.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Mostly realistic characters but further development needed, will probably be provided in following books.  Would have made this book way too large.  Enjoyed the premise,  has a lot of promise for the series.  No memorable typos or poor grammar.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on July 18, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Henry is a human who gets taken out by a flying lawnmower. He wakes up about 100 years in the future not knowing where he is or what has happened to him. It turns out that scientists uploaded Henry's mind to a computer file—including all his emotions and memories. So when Henry is awakened, he is shocked to find out he is essentially an AI overseeing operations on a Military ship in route to our nearest neighboring star. Not everyone understands Henry. The captain thinks he is nothing more than software to be used when needed—and he rarely sees the need for Henry. After a rocky start, Henry finds himself with many of his permissions on board ship denied and basically allowed only to monitor the outside sensors. On top of all this, Henry has his own guardian AI. This program, called GARY for short, has a very narrow view of what Henry is allowed to do during the long years the crew is asleep. If Henry asks the wrong question, it can cause Gary to start a routine to wake up the captain which is the last thing Henry wants.This book is a hoot to read. Henry gets into all sorts of trouble as he tries his best to keep the crew safe and see that their ship gets to its destination without incident. There is a serious side to the story too. Aliens have taken up residence in the Kuiper belt and are building some kind of structure for want of a better term. The crew must investigate this site before they can head for the stars. As the crew heads for the Kuiper belt things do not go as planned. If memory serves, this is when Henry tries to offer unsolicited advice and is sanctioned by the captain—permissions begin to be taken away. Henry is shocked by the captain's attitude toward him but can do nothing about it but live within the guidelines the captain sets.I thoroughly enjoyed this story and am looking forward to book 2. I was surprised when Scott came out with this story as I know he has a couple of others in the works. He's really working hard to give us fans excellent SciFi to read. Thanks Scott!!!
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on June 11, 2024

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Although one can't say it's unique, I've rarely seen a story that considers using a reconstituted human that was originally alive. Although the concept is refreshing, a think the delivery is stereo typical.  The captain is unreasonable in his criticism, and is reluctant to learn from his errors. I would expect a sterling crew such as makes up the interchange to be more polished in their conduct.  It isn't their banter, as its the lack of any cohesion when performing their tactics such as breaking and running rather than a coordinated withdrawal.  Even the idea of a battle tested marine sergeant being such a milktoast doesn't fly very well. I also consider it poor tactics to have acquired such treasures as the codex, the drones, and the information provided by the friendlies, and risk their loss by proceeding forward into another unknown hot zone.  In the end, I don't think highly of the character development or decisions made, but I find the basic premise interesting enough that I will try to read the sequel.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on April 25, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I am a fairly avid reader of sci fi, in the serial or series format.  Probably a residual of my childhood growing up watching Star Trek on television.When I first saw this book, I thought that the idea had been done before in the "Bobiverse" books, where human personalities become flight computers, essentially.  I thought I'd be able to digest this book easily enough after that series.  Maybe I was wrong, as I read most of this "I Robot" series.  The similarities ended at the plot device and the personalities made this it's own story.Recommended reading.

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: At the beginning, the reawakening of Henry as a "reconstituted mind" or RM is somewhat reminiscent of Bob (the Bobiverse series) but Henry never integrates fully to the ship he is destined to be and starts playing second fiddle to a lot of small-time bickering between the humans on board. productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the Netherlands on September 18, 2024

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: Flying lawnmowers and evil aliens - perfect!
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: This is book 1 in a new series by Scott Bartlett. The first thing that came to mind after reading it was wow, this is how to begin a series.The author got me right at the start of the book when he ‘killed’ off the main character with a flying lawnmower and made him into a sentient AI. One of the main threads running through the book is how the various characters interact and treat the sentient AI that used to be alive.The story takes us on a journey through near and far space in order to evaluate and deal with a possible/probable threat to Earth. The story was fun, interesting and moved at a good pace. It takes place over 80 years (the travel time to the far space location). The author continued to build on the plot and the characters as the book went along. There are incidents that occur during the 80 years that affect both the ship and crew. The ending of this book leads into the next, which the author is in the process of researching and developing.I found the main characters to be well written and relatable. They were interesting and their actions were usually, based on their personality, what you would expect. There were characters that I liked and some I didn’t (again, based on their personality or actions).I thought the tech the author created was good and reasonable based on what could be available in the near future.I thoroughly enjoyed the book, gave it 5 stars and I recommend it based on the above.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Jaxon Reed understands "space operas"--great diversions from life's cares
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: The Farmer series was just a wonderful series of escapades.  "High Tech"; AI; furious beastly predators; evil scheming villains; heroic good guys; some PG romance; miracles that "save the day"--it had it all.SO...with proven capability in his art and his audience, the author expands his story and his core themes with flare and competence.  Old friends resurface; new allies are found; loaded with "PEW PEW PEW" battles; hints of BIG THINGS SIMMERING--just a fun romp.  It's a quick and easy read, and it held my attention until the end.  If you want deep thinking, explorations of philosophy, evocative/profound description, etc, then go read War and Peace [I dare you to finish it; I didn't].  But to "get away from it all" and KNOWING that truth and justice and honor will always win in the end, you can't go wrong with this.  Eagerly awaiting the next book in series.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Almost a good story and almost well written
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Way too many coincidences to form the team. Space is big until you need a certain person to appear on the space port you happen to be on.Super deadly bots but they can't hit people lying in the open (on the deck of a space port).An assassin that can be invisible (basically) and shoot lasers from her hands, but the out of battery at the must convenient times (for the story, not convenient for the protagonist.)The first few chapters are choppy. More like a first draft than a polished book.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on December 4, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Another great start to a new series
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Picking up shortly after the end of System Alignment, we are reintroduced to Bo Duckworth as he deals with the fallout of doing the right thing. Arriving at Athos station where he expects to work as a miner, he encounters two Phaethon Corp employees and joins in their adventure.Mr. Reed is off to another great start with this new series, full of running firefights, chutes and ladders style hollowed out asteroids, and the sly humor present in the previous Milky Way books. There are some fantasy elements here too, with the outer space version of Imps, Ogres, and Trolls making an appearance. Some well placed appearances by Tom Savage help tie everything together.This is a really fun read and I'm looking forward to the rest of the series.

bookDescription: The late Henry Morgan has been a starship's AI for centuriesBeing the governing mind of a military starship has not been without its challenges. productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Another Interesting Act in this Sweeping Space Opera!
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: If you have read the first 3 books in this series, you already know that this series is truly a space opera as the subtitle suggests - grand, a bit pretentious and pleasantly moralizing about the human condition.  Revolution succinctly tells the tale of what happens when life gets too good for a society’s citizens - they tear it down.  All the volumes have been amazingly engaging - it is hard to put down.  Imaginative, and with a lot of action sequences- and most importantly the author keeps things moving, with no long slogs through exposition that plagues many other long multi-volume series.  Character development is light (in keeping with opera) and the technical aspects plausible enough not to distract.  Well done, Mr. Bartlett!

bookDescription: After a risky hyperspace jump, Captain Archer Devereaux arrives in an uninhabited sector of the Orion Spur.He finds a long-abandoned ship with technology far advanced beyond any known in his region of space. Even more puzzling, the ship is of human construction. As the ship regains functionality, traps left by mutineers threaten the lives of Archer and the tiny crew aboard the derelict.When he succeeds in bringing Defender back to Alliance space, an idealistic scientist posts critical information regarding Defender’s advanced technology. The Nemeans and Scyllans press for peace talks—a delaying tactic while they evaluate the information dump. When they learn that implementation is at least a year away, they break the truce violently, attempting to capture the Alliance and EU delegates during peace talks on Earth.Archer suffers devastating losses in the attack, which he has difficulty processing emotionally. Bette has her own issues of this type, and the two part on uncertain terms. She then disappears, leaving a cryptic note.Defender’s Awakening is a pulse-pounding space opera of interstellar intrigue, moral dilemmas, and fragile emotional bonds. It’s perfect for fans of epic sci-fi adventures, where heroes must not only battle their foes but also control their hearts.Book 4 of a new military science fiction series from award-winning author John J. Spearman. It's perfect for fans of Rick Partlow, Nathan Lowell, and Jeffery H. Haskell!

title: Species Seventeen: Book 1 of Humanity's Leap
author: C.S. Garrand
breadCrumbs: Kindle Store > Kindle eBooks > Science Fiction & Fantasy > Science Fiction > Military > Space Marine

attributes.value: #3,571 in Kindle Store (See Top 100 in Kindle Store) #10 in Space Exploration Science Fiction eBooks#16 in Hard Science Fiction (Kindle Store)#17 in Space Marine Science Fiction eBooks

bookDescription:
Book One of Humanity’s Leap.An alien artifact is discovered by an artificial intelligence owned by a small, autonomous mining corporation operating in the asteroid belt. After extensive reverse engineering, Galactic Planetary Resources develops technology that propels humanity to expand rapidly beyond Earth over the next sixty years. These advancements ultimately lead to another astonishing discovery: a transit gate hidden in Earth’s solar system for thousands of years—and now, it can be used.
A cast of engaging, well-developed characters aboard the corporate starship Audacious discover more than they ever dreamed possible, including the revelation that this isn’t the first time humanity has ventured into the stars.
A team of United Earth Hegemony Marines, led by Staff Sergeant Dixon, is requisitioned to assist Captain Rohit Mishra, scientist Irina Orlova, and others as they push the boundaries of what humanity can achieve—while trying to convince Earth’s government to let them do it.
Narrated in first person by CAIPARR, the sentient artificial intelligence owned by GPR, the novel explores the ethics of artificial intelligence, humanity’s existential beliefs, and the age-old question: should we do something, simply because we can?

bookDescription:
When Thomas heard the cries for help, he didn’t hesitate to do the right thing. It was his chance for redemption.
Until everything went wrong.
The cave should have been deserted. The perfect place to hide. Instead, it’s crawling with soldiers and engineers working to unearth the impossible:
Excalibur.
Deep beneath the mountain, she’s waited centuries to be found. Not a sword in the stone, but a starship. And according to the onboard AI, Thomas is the only one who can command her.
Now he's on the run across a galaxy more astonishing and treacherous than he ever imagined, where magic and technology intertwine and ancient powers lurk in the shadows. Relentlessly hunted and hopelessly lost, he needs to learn fast if he wants to survive. Only his greatest challenge isn't training to pilot a starship. It's accepting that he, of all people, is responsible for reigniting the hope of a fallen kingdom.
King Arthur’s legend may be complete, but his is just beginning…

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Well it's not going to blow your socks off it's still worth a read
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: If you're a fan of Arthurian legend or unlikely heroes, then this work of fiction might be right for you. There are moments in the story that the author describes certain things more than once, but the writing doesn't lack because of it.The characters are nice and have interesting personalities. The concepts and entry level knowledge of science isn't intense and I believe that this book is particularly suited for young readers. But be warned there are some intense violent battles with magic weapons and swords however not necessarily too graphic. I'd recommend reading it a little yourself before deciding on whether this book is right for your kids if you're worried about that.:)The plotline can be a little predictable at times and at other times might throw a few twists your way. The grammar flows well and you find yourself often rooting for the protagonist.In summary I recommend this book if your looking for a new series to fill in time between other series or if you have a particular wish to read this series.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I really enjoyed your book it was unexpected the story line was original and unexpected. I hope when I get my book published it will give others the joy your book has given me. I have enjoyed Syfy for many years now and at 70 I find that in so many ways it has a way of imitating real life. It can explain old mysteries in new ways that are not only entertaining but also therapeutic and even healing. Life is an amazing thing filled with so many unexplained things and Syfy stories are able to help give us a small view of a universe of possibilities if we keep an open mind to them. Thank you again for your story. I can't wait to read the next chapter in Thomas's adventure.

bookDescription: They say you can’t go home again……especially if you’re the governing mind for an interstellar military starship.It's official: Sergeant Henry Morgan has now spent more time as a starship than he spent dead. His mission is more than a century old, but in some ways, he feels like it's just begun.A desperate distress call from Earth has brought him back to his old cosmic stomping grounds, for your standard save-humanity-from-extinction-by-alien-constructs operation.But Henry needs to realize something: while his species might be the new kid on the galactic block, it is not without its secrets. Many of them deep and dark, with implications that reach back to the time when he himself walked the Earth on two legs.In some ways, humanity has become more alien than the extraterrestrials. And if Henry can't figure out what this means - fast - he's going to have serious problems keeping himself and his crew safe.Download I, Starship: The Earth We Knew and grab the edge of your seat for this bold new space opera.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Books 3 and 4 of the I, Starship series find the RM Sgt Henry Morgan and the crew of the Interchange far from home and moving from pickle.to pickle.Book 3 is a sort of coming of age story for Henry, focusing on him as the ship travels between systems, watching him grapple with his growth and the psychological implications of his existence. His internal journey provides the basis of a strong story and I enjoyed it very much.Book 4 was more of a political thriller, as the ship finds itself caught up in a system's cycle of revolution and counter-revelution. Henry is forced to take an even bigger hand in the action, and the book ends with a sinister cliffhanger that will keep us eagerly awaiting the release of Book 5.Also, as always, kudos to Mark Boyett's narration for providing depth and humanity (even in Henry's case) to Bartlett's story and characters.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: A fun read, for the most part
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I really enjoyed this book.  It's an amalgamation of Horatio Hornblower, Star Trek, and Tom Clancy. The British versus the Soviets in outer space. Sounds strange, but it works. I particularly liked the fact that, unlike Star Trek, there are enlisted people, and they play a significant role in the story.The battle scenes, and the military technology employed, were particularly well done.Two minor quibbles. There was altogether too much saluting. Neither the British not the American navies salute indoors. Unless you are covered (wearing a hat) you cannot render a salute. Second, it's a fallacy that there can only be one captain on a ship. U. S. Navy aircraft carriers have two, and usually three. The captain of the ship is a Captain O-6. The CAG, the commander of the air wing, is also a Captain O-6. And, since most carriers have an admiral embarked, his assistant is called the Flag Captain, and is also a Captain O-6. Furthermore, a captain in the Marines is a different rank entirely, an O-3, equivalent to a Lieutenant in the Navy. So there would have been no reason to promote the Captain of the Marine detachment to Major.The military quibbles aside, I did have one significant problem with the book, which is why I didn't give it five stars.  At around the 50% mark, Captain Halberd is assigned to go on a publicity tour, during which he has affairs with multiple women.  I found the politics boring and the sex disgusting.  I think the book would have been better without that entire episode.Nonetheless, I would read the next book in the series, if it were available on Kindle Unlimited. I'm too cheap to pay for it.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: What a trip! In a series like this, it's difficult not to have, if not an emotional connection, certainly an empathetic one with the main character. If I had the choice in these circumstances, I think I would make different choices. But, I live in reality, Earth-bound with no practical grasp of the choices afforded the humans in this Sci-Fi 'Space Opera' by author Scott Bartlett. If you enjoy expanding your imagination, any book by Scott Bartlett will do the trick, and 'Tin Can Combat' definitely will. -Mr.Bill

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Last stand of the Tin can sailors
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Your story felt familiar. As a follower of Naval history, I found your story remarkably similar to the true non-fiction story about Taffy 3 and the battle off Samar.  Right down to the makeup of the battle group and Bull Halseys battle group being lured away by a decoy. You really dug deep here.  It even depicted the incredible last stand of the USS Johnston and Commander Ernest E. Evans.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Poor Henry. What does a bot have to do to be noticed and/appreciated around here? Helping Captain Seemey fighting the Scree didn't endear himself like he hoped. Being bestowed with the Codex from Polyhistor seemed to anger the Captain, just because.....well, Henry just had to deal with it. But Captain Seemey would really go crazy if he found out Henry, and only Henry, had been given the key to access the Codex by Polyhistor.The Interchange was a formidable ship, but needed repairs before leaving the Toliman System, and Henry was filled with joy that he could help. He was sure, though, no one would appreciate this, either.The 2nd book in the "I, Starship: A Space Opera" book, picks up right after the 1st. The pace is fast and furious. This book grabs your attention in a way that makes it hard to put down. Scott Bartlett has a knack for keeping his readers on the edge of their seats, so carve out time to read this book. It's totally worth it!

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: It seems that sergeant Morgan's dialogue gets in the way of the story.  Dialogue seems kind of stilted no matter who is talking, but attempting to keep Morgan acting like a newbie gets in the way.  He seems so brainless for a combat veteran with a rank of sergeant.  I'd expect him to quickly use the simulator to make himself indispensable.  Also, what happened to Campbell?  I would have expected her to bring some reason into the story to counter the captain, but she goes off the rails, and starts taking attitude, and being disrespectful.  The story is improved, but we've diverted away from the original concept that the story is about the sergeant Henry Morgan.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Out of the frying pan (as they say!)
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Marine sergeant Henry Morgan wakes one day to discover that he's now a disembodied, electronically reconstituted mind controlling many of the functions of a huge starship. He still thinks and feels Human, but must come to grips with his new reality. Despite being treated as just a machine by the captain and crew, Henry manages to help save the day as they overcome impossible odds to defeat an enemy alien vessel that has wiped out another alien civilization, who bestow on Henry a cache of knowledge that only he can access.Now the starship continues to seek others threatened by the same enemy, and together with new allies must face what appears to be certain annihilation.Will Sergeant Morgan be able to help? And will he even be allowed to??
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2024

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I like the way the author uses a Marine soldier who died in an accident, was placed in cryogenic sleep, then almost one hundred years later, revive his brain and incorporates its memories into electronic data in a “black box” type storage device.  All this because Earth has noticed alarming activity out in the stars.  Humanity has built the first and most advanced spacecraft ever built to investigate and hopefully stop the systematic destruction noted out by Alpha Centuri. The trip will take in excess is 82 years requiring the crew to go into cryo sleep on a 10 year rotational basis. They need a “human” mind that can think out of the box (no pun intended) and not tire.  AI’s can’t.  They can only do as they are programmed.  Sounds great!  But no.  The captain hates AI’s. Others have put an AI inline to monitor and restrict Henry.  What can go wrong?!There is drama, strife, hopelessness, loss and a whole gamut of issues form the crew and Henry.  I really like how the author humanizes Henry, including how can a human mind remain sane in an environment where there is no sleep, no one to talk to due to the crew in cryo, other than a “by the book, unyielding AI that can’t recognize serious issues!Sorry for being long winded.  In short… this is a good book to read!  Enjoy it!

aPlusContent.title: From the Publisher
aPlusContent.rawText:
From the Publisher
Impossible odds meet impossible choices in a thrilling space adventure 
Solarhaven Alliance Marine veteran Jace Hawthorne only wants to protect his family while surviving under the oppressive rule of alien overlords. He's heard rumors of fiery rebellions and buried alien technologies, fleeting hopes that allies are waiting to overthrow their cruel leaders. But to Jace, those rumors are nothing but unsubstantiated gossip. 
Until a routine smuggling job turns catastrophic and lands him in a world of shadows and intrigue. He faces a monumental decision that could save humanity--or doom it. Jace quickly learns the most important choices aren't the ones you make but the ones that make you.

modules.text:
Solarhaven Alliance Marine veteran Jace Hawthorne only wants to protect his family while surviving under the oppressive rule of alien overlords. He's heard rumors of fiery rebellions and buried alien technologies, fleeting hopes that allies are waiting to overthrow their cruel leaders. But to Jace, those rumors are nothing but unsubstantiated gossip. 
Until a routine smuggling job turns catastrophic and lands him in a world of shadows and intrigue. He faces a monumental decision that could save humanity--or doom it. Jace quickly learns the most important choices aren't the ones you make but the ones that make you.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This is the first book of a space-based Science Fiction series. As such, it gives some background and current-day events before getting into the 'meat' of the story.The story starts out focusing on Jace. He's a military combat veteran of the opposition forces to the current government. This led to him spending time in a government prison. Upon his release, his only viable option for employment is to work for a shadowy organization. The only reason he remains on his home planet and works for them is to assist his ailing mother and his retired combat veteran father. As the story unfolds, Jace is forced into making hard decisions that affect his future.As a reader, I love that the book had a touch of mystery and intrigue. I'm looking forward to reading the next books in the series.Disclaimer: I was invited, along with other readers, to read this book. I voluntarily agreed to do so. Above are my honest thoughts on this book.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Some Years You Can't Get A Break
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Archer Devereaux can't get a break.  An up & coming young navalofficer in the Phlegraean fleet, his career took a nose dive whenhe was found sleeping with the wife of his commanding officer.  Hehad no idea who she was, and that in fact she had specially pickedhim out because she was furious at her husband (it turned out sheactually liked Devereaux, so she was sorry about it, but damagedone).  The fleet is not particularly puritan, and everything wasconsensual and out of the chain of command, so Arch was cleared,officially.  Unofficially, his name was mud, especially with Academygraduates.The outbreak of war, and his ongoing success in battle, along withthe turnover of war-revealed dead-wood in the Admiralty ranks seemto have Devereaux's star on the rise again, but somehow he keepsgetting assigned to diplomatic missions which always end in bloodand disorder for some (as yet mysterious) reason.These are very straight-forward, low-key "He did this, and then hedid that" books which work better in that presentation than youmight think.  The battles are low-key as well.  Ships are veryexpensive and it is uncommon to have more than three on each sideengaging.  Space is also large, so there is a lot of hunt & seekwith weeks between engagements, and people are people, so there isalways backbiting and corruption in high places.  There is also onewoman who keeps turning up in all of Arch's troubles (sometimesseemingly as the cause of them), and she may be The One, though,as I said, it's a pretty casual setting, and Arch manages to findother friendly companionship (with benefits) along the way.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: But the space navy battles lack some essential details. There’s never any issues with detecting enemy ships. In fact there’s no mention of how ships are detected at all. There’s no real question of communications, or emissions control. Drones can explode on or near ships. Why aren’t the drones carrying nuclear warheads? Why aren’t they using nuclear bomb pumped laser fire?Everyone has FTL communications nearly all the time. It seems to me that would allow headquarters to micromanage operations, just as happens in our reality.Why did the fleet merger conference have about zero security? As soon as the details were revealed, I thought, “Ut oh, there’s trouble.”Computer security in the book is not as good as it was in the 1960s in the US. It seems like bad actors can do as they wish to computer systems without any problems.For a better example of the genre, read Chain of Command, by Frank Chadwick.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Starship Troopers is an amazing novel and almost nothing like that abortion of a movie by Verhoeven, who thought Heinlein a Neo-Fascist. That’s his depiction in the movie, but it doesn’t resemble the novel except very superficially. Frankly, it’s a scandal that a man was given the job of directing the adaptation to intentionally smear the novel, its ideas, and the man, himself.  But, on to the novel...It’s vintage Heinlein—imaginative, but with a tangible flavor of realism and an accurate anthropology. The characters are well-developed and the action satisfying. One of the unique things about Heinlein is his strong sense of the moral and an interesting aspect of this novel, in particular, is the political moral philosophy that underpins it—the notion that the only people that should have political power (the voter franchise) are those that have demonstrated the moral commitment of sacrifice for society—indeed, the human race. That is, those unwilling to put society above their own interests are unfit to wield political power, which amounts to the authority to wield force and violence. Philosophers and theologians have observed similar things. For example, Martin Luther’s concept of the Left-Hand Kingdom, asserts similar concepts—the State wields the sword for the benefit of society (and, for Luther, The Church) to create order and protect people from chaos and threats. Heinlein has his own twist on these ideas. They’re intriguing—and, convincing.It’s also my understanding that this is the first Sci-Fi novel to realistically depict military life. I can’t say for sure, because I have an insufficient understanding of the Sci-Fi cannon and I’ve never served in the military. Heinlein did know military life, as he graduated from the US Naval Academy and served 5 years as a naval officer before being retired because of an illness—tuberculosis, I believe.  All I can say is that it is believable. It doesn’t just focus on the actions and action, but the inner life, attitudes, and thought patterns of the military man (and woman). Needless to say, the movie completely misses the mark on this point also.I first read this novel decades ago and thought it terrific then—well, no surprise there, since it won the Hugo Award before the award was infested by political correctness. I thought it worth a re-read, especially in today’s political climate—the ideas here won’t be popular with people who think that government (really, other people) owes them free stuff. Even after decades, there were certain scenes that had stuck in my mind all that time. If you believe that the mark of a successful novel is its ability to stick in your mind, then this novel delivers in spades. Still, after reading it again I was surprised by how many substantive things I had forgotten, which is a testament to its depth.Originally marketed as one of Heinlein’s juvenile novels, it really doesn’t fit well in that genre. It’s shorter than many of his novels, but not as short as the juveniles such as “Have Spacesuit, Will Travel” (my favorite Heinlein novel of that genre). This is a serious book that explores serious ideas, so adults will find it satisfying. Nevertheless, I do recommend it for young adults. We’d do well to make it a regular part of the literature cannon taught in late middle school and high school, as it forces one to think about the relationship between responsibilities and rights, as well as economic concepts such as “value” and markets. If people are to be voting citizens, then they should be familiar with the ideas in this novel, even if they ultimately disagree with them. You can’t have a useful opinion on the concepts, though, if you don’t know what they are. Thinking about ideas is never a waste.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on March 4, 2019

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: It changed my life 64 years ago
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I first read “Starship Troopers” when it was first published in 1959, right after I graduated from high school. Now, 64 years later, I have read it once more. I am a retired submarine officer who came up through the ranks like Rico. As I look back on my life through the lens of this remarkable book, I can see that it played a significant role in who I became.Some critics have panned “Starship Troopers” as nothing more than a series of civics infodumps interspersed with a thin storyline. While I understand where they come from, I disagree with that characterization. From what I know about Heinlein (I never met him), he led the libertarian wing of hard science fiction throughout the 50s, 60s, and 70s. He had a keen understanding of what Ayn Rand called the “Objective Universe.” He saw what had happened to the United States in his time (the 1950s), compared with what the founders had created. With insight clearer than virtually anyone else back then, he saw how things could be. “Starship Troopers” is a novel that shows exactly how his vision might be realized. He didn’t tell us how to do it, but rather showed us what it would be like if we did it. Throughout the novel, he regales us with the thoughts of experts who expound to their captive students on their conception (and, of course, Heinlein’s conception) of what he calls “History and Moral Philosophy.” These lectures, that comprise an integral part of the novel, became the underpinnings of who I became as an officer and a man.As I look back on my life of 82 years, I can see how profoundly Heinlein’s “History and Moral Philosophy” affected me personally. Ironically, in my post-military career, I write hard science fiction. I do not consciously emulate Heinlein, but my award-winning writings have frequently been compared to his—something I take as a great compliment.The bottom line here is, no matter what you may have heard about “Starship Troopers,” read it, and you will gain a new perspective on how things are and how they might be. I highly recommend it without equivocation. It is one of the very best hard science fiction novels ever written.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2024

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: Deeper than you'd think, an excellent read.
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: Robert A. Heinlein's Starship Troopers has finally made it in ebook form to the kindle, i've been waiting for this for a while and having never read it before I can happily say it was worth the wait and I can see why to many it is a classic. Those of you who have seen the films (I love the first and detest the others) may have a vague idea of the plot but the films are a pale imitation missing so much the book has to offer.The story follows the career of Johnnie Rico as a Trooper for the federation in a far off fascist future. Despite being a military sci-fi novel it has a surprising amount of political commentary running throughout adding an interesting layer of depth that a lot of modern military sci-fi novels really lack. In the future the only people that can vote have to have worked for the federation to earn citizenship, they have to have earned the right and put the good of the whole above the individual but it's not that simple as Johnnie finds out.Though Rico's reason for joining started as a political choice it soon turns into the look at the life of a mobile infantry trooper, over half the book is about his training alone, about what really makes a soldier in the future. Most of the cadets don't make it through training, nevermind to serve their term to be citizens.The way Starship Troopers is written from Johnnies point of view makes everything remarkably clear as the poor lad is as confused about events as the reader so nothing is left unexplained yet it never gets bogged down or feels slow, it's all pretty engrossing.I think that's what was so good about it, yes the bug war is mentioned towards the end but there's no resolution. It's not a book about saving worlds, about good vs evil, there's no distinct point. Just a career view of a trooper in a politically different future. It's a fascinating read I recommend to any sci-fi fan.+ Interesting political sub theme.+ Rico's training is detailed.+ Well written universe, clear and concise.+ Interesting plot focus, a little different.
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 8, 2015

bookDescription:
When the aliens evolve, so does the threat against humanity in this thrilling sequel to Scorpio that finds Alex Archer in an epic battle of survival against the odds and the alien invaders.
Alex Archer is a soldier now, the only civilian survivor from Scorpio to join the NAC Defense Corps. With their training complete, Alex and her friend Private Isa Cressey find themselves on emergency combat deployment with their new unit. The destination is the Alpha Corvi system, where an allied warship has vanished. Alex can guess why.
Her fears prove true—Alpha Corvi is under new ownership. Alex must face the monsters from her childhood again as her regiment mounts a rescue operation to find and save the planet’s colonists. But this time, there is something terrifyingly different about their enemy. The Corps has evolved to meet the threat, but the Lankies have adapted as well—and they are more lethal than ever. What began as a rescue turns into a desperate fight for survival for Alex and her new friends, stranded on a hostile world forty-nine light-years from Earth. And the only way home goes right through the Lankies.

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: A good one, among the best of the saga
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: It is a follow-up of the life of Alex Archer and everything fits rather well in the Lankiverse: No big explanations about its but no hollow pew-pew either.The length is appropriated. The story is not stretched way too much as it happens with some contemporary SF books and the end is not an absurd cliffhanger to let the readers waiting for the next installment. It is basically auto-conclusive thouhg it lets the things rather open and in a good sense. All in all, this is perhaps one of the best books in the saga and it points to fresh developments that fit with the previous ones.Just one or two tiny details that rubbed me wrong. For instance, Alex keeps on calling "sir" to every sargent and NCO she founds and no one of them chews her out for that. And burbers and PRC do not mix but in the first books of the series they mixed basically OK...

bookDescription: Money and power.Van knows it makes the stars go around, but in the wrong hands, it can lead to disaster.Armed with new ships, new fighters, and an iron will, he'll lead the Fist of Orion to one last fight against an ancient enemy—the Stillness.For three generations, the Tudors have battled an organization dedicated to power at any cost, but as the war heats up, the Stillness have partnered with a race who regard humanity as more than an enemy.Humans are. . . an opportunity.It's going to take more than ships and guns to beat the Stillness—the job requires money. Lots and lots of money. But the Fist has a friend in the banking industry, and with Dayna, and Tor, and Kay, earth will enter a second kind of war.A war to control the economy of the stars.Using their new comms, their old ways, and their own grit, the crew of the Fafnir enter a final desperate battle to keep Earth free from tyranny— -- If they can convince the leaders of Earth to play fair.It's a tall order, but Van is used to big jobs, and this time, he's not playing defense. For the Fist, it's time. . . to attack.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Chapter 15 paragraph 1 states that Van is one-quarter Hu'warde because his Grandmother, Valint is Hu'warde. Van is a minimum of one-half Hu'warde because his Mother Jocelyn is also Hu'warde. This appears to be a grievous error made by Author Maggert. Its highly doubtful that J. N. Chaney would've made an error of this magnitude. I have read too many books in series by that Author Chaney that had no issues with continuity.  So I will lay the blame at the feet of the Secondary Author Terry Maggert, the beta readers, and the Editor. Let's not forget the AI that somehow missed the Family Tree legend in the Preview area in the front of this book.  Disappointing to read that knowing so many did not take the opportunity to update that paragraph. To await months for this book to finally arrive, makes this error absolutely difficult to digest.

bookDescription:
An alien attack leaves them adrift in space.Survive, rebuild, and rejoin the war.
Fresh out of the Academy, Ensign Cole Jackson’s first posting to Freedom couldn’t have come at a worse time. All over the Alliance, planets and colonies are suddenly under attack by the vicious Coven Empire.Freedom and her sister ship, Hood, are ambushed by alien warships, leaving Hood drifting dead in the void.Cole is ordered to salvage parts from the powerless Hood, but when he arrives on the unpowered hulk, Freedom is called away, marooning him and a group of malcontent techs in deep space.With the timer on survival ticking down, Cole must find the confidence to take control, whip his tiny crew into shape, bring Hood back to life––repairing communications, propulsion and even weapons.He's got one chance to transform the derelict ship into a combat-ready vessel. One he can take into battle and alterthe course of the war.Don't miss the start of this science fiction thrill ride about a crew of young soldiers mustering the courage to fight back against both a vicious alien enemy, and the terrifying void of being stranded in space. It's perfect for fans of Daniel Gibbs, J.N. Chaney, and Vaughn Heppner!

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: I'm givin' her all she's got, Captain!!
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This book had just about everything... Warp speed! Impulse engines! Exploding consoles! and a complete absence of seatbelts! Apparently the technology for seat restraints was lost in some earlier era.Aside from that, for its length, this book did a great job of creating characters, building a story, and keeping your attention! It's a great tale of a bunch of greenies showing courage under fire, and a captain doing everything in his power to save lives! It's also a story of a bunch of young engineers rallying behind their captain and giving it all to get the job done!It's not hard sci-fi, and it's not Hamlet. But it does what it is meant to do; entertain. So if you like books that harken back to the golden years of sci-fi, with bodies flying from explosions, enemy vessels that dwarf anything the good guys have, and people facing odds that would make you crawl in an escape pod, hit the eject and self-destruct buttons at the same time, you'll like this book!

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: An excellent read, albeit flawed by hard science
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This is an extremely well written novel, entertaining and enthralling.  It kept me engaged from the first page to the last - in fact, I enjoyed it so much that having first borrowed it on Kindle Unlimited, I then bought a copy, to give the author the benefit of double earning.  I'm looking forward to the next two books in the series.That said, the book's major flaw - and it's a big one - is that it ignores the limitations of hard science in so blatant a way as to make it difficult to suspend disbelief.  I'm not talking about standard tropes like faster-than-light travel, or that sort of thing:  almost every SF author uses them, and we're used to them.  What grates is when a spaceship can brake from speeds greater than light to a standstill in the time it takes to read this sentence, or when a spaceship is used to ram another spaceship at faster-than-light speeds.  You and I know that even the barest touch of ship upon ship at such speeds would produce one of the most stupendous explosions in the galaxy, and utterly destroy both craft;  yet, in this book, it becomes a tactic that the hero uses more than once.  At low speeds (I'm talking tens, rather than hundreds or thousands of miles per hour) ramming becomes feasible.  Any faster, and it's a non-starter (except as a rather flashy way to commit suicide).  For such flaws, I had to deduct one star from what would otherwise have been a five-star review.However, the book is still very entertaining, and I liked it enough that I've pre-ordered the next two volumes in the series.  I just wish the author would be a bit more careful in crossing the scientifically believable line!
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on March 23, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This is a very fine story. I can't say anything bad about it. The book kept my interest the whole way through!! I didn't spend much time on that because the battles were shaping up and being fought page after page.Mr. Simon, if you are reading this, I would give it ten stars if I could! Well done and am moving on to the next book.

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: WOW... best military SciFi I have read in a while
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: This is a very long book... and could easily have been split into two of them. So I started it with some trepidation, not knowing how far I would get through before I gave up.Instead, I found that it was hard to put it down and I devoured it at every opportunity, finishing it over a long weekend. The action was remorseless yet gripping and with different scenarios each major event. I dare say that much didn't conform to our current understanding of physics, but it was handled in such a way that it didn't seem to matter.The central character was unexpectedly thrust into his role but rose to the occasion and became a genuine hero, a natural leader... all whilst coming across as a thoroughly pleasant character, doubts and fears not withstanding.I don't often give 5 stars but I didn't feel I could do otherwise in this case... and I am seriously considering buying the remaining 2 books in the series, although book 2 is based on a planet.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: very hard to read because almost every sentence is treated as a paragraph.  no clue why anyone would write this way. learn how to write in English please. Update: thought I should clarify. Almost every sentence is separated by a blank line. In a few cases, a few sentences may form a paragraph, but most commonly every sentence is separated like a paragraph. Reading this is a bit like trying to read while traveling down a road full of potholes, you keep getting jarred and have to take a second to get back to where you were. A well written book should flow, word to word, sentence to sentence, and paragraph to paragraph leading the reading smoothly through the story. This book is the direct opposite of that.

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: Fun & fast paced, do yourself a favour
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: Jaxon Reed is a relatively new author to me - what a great find!  Earlier in the year I came across the Steam & Aether series. Bear in mind each book in these series are interconnected and have cliffhangers. Good thing is that you never have to wait for long to get the next instalment. Guaranteed when I arrive home that evening this will be my night done!

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Tbe Eldra’kaarn warship is the key player in this adventure, along with Jace and Caera
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Jace Hawthorne and Caera Frost uncover an Eldra'kaarn warship, the Revenant. Only Jace and his cat, Shadow, are imbued with the temporal microbes that allow him to communicate with and control Revenant. Until they find more of the Eldra'kaarn microbes, only Jace can use any of the functions of the warship and he has a lot to learn. Fortunately, the Revenant AI, ECHO, helps him use the ship functions and weapons. In addition to some pretty advanced weaponry, Revenant has powerful shields and the ability to cloak and move unseen. Delivering the warship to the Rising Dawn is the plan, but until more Eldra'kaarn microbes are found only Jace can operate the Revenant. Can one ship make a difference against the Overlords? Even one as powerful as the Revenant?Powerful characters fill the cast of the Rising Dawn and Revenant. The Revenant is a pretty potent character itself with ECHO speaking for the warship. Jace, Son of the Lion, is saddled with high expectations. Is he stepping up? We'll see. Jace's romance with Caera is back-burnered by their duties to Revenant and Rising Dawn, but it still simmers. Shadow is another mysterious character, slinking around and appearing mysteriously in unexpected parts of the warship. Rising Dawn is a strong presence in the storyline, demanding allegiance and providing hope in a hopeless galaxy. The storyline presents one action-packed adventure after another! No time to catch your breath between sequences of combat, preparation and execution! This is another great read!

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Turn the page of a different author's story!
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This guy gives new meaning to bloviating and pedantry!  He has turned a great novelette story into a multi book treatise that smacks of 'paid by the word!'  Waded through the first book and quit the series as it was an up hill battle to read.  This guy's writing does not 'flow,' instead each word clings!  Not a good thing.  The concept of the story is interesting enough that I went back days later and started the second book in hopes that maybe the author's agent might have banged some sense into the writers head.  Not so!  Even with reading the last couple of sentences of each page I could not hack the story and bailed after 2/3rd's of the second book and this time for good!

bookDescription: After a decade, acclaimed science fiction master John Scalzi returns to the galaxy of the Old Man's War series with the long awaited seventh book, The Shattering PeaceTHE PEACE IS SHATTERINGFor a decade, peace has reigned in interstellar space. A tripartite agreement between the Colonial Union, the Earth, and the alien Conclave has kept the forces of war at bay, even when some would have preferred to return to the fighting and struggle of former times. For now, more sensible heads have prevailed – and have even championed unity.But now, there is a new force that threatens the hard-maintained peace: The Consu, the most advanced intelligent species humans have ever met, are on the cusp of a species-defining civil war. This war is between Consu factions... but nothing the Consu ever do is just about them. The Colonial Union, the Earth and the Conclave have been unwillingly dragged into the conflict, in the most surprising of ways.Gretchen Trujillo is a mid-level diplomat, working in an unimportant part of the Colonial Union bureaucracy. But when she is called to take part in a secret mission involving representatives from every powerful faction in space, what she finds there has the chance to redefine the destinies of humans and aliens alike... or destroy them forever.OTHER TOR BOOKS BY JOHN SCALZIAgent to the StarsThe Android’s DreamFuzzy NationRedshirtsYour Hate Mail Will Be Graded:A Decade of Whatever, 1998–2008The Kaiju Preservation SocietyStarter VillainWhen the Moon Hits Your EyeTHE OLD MAN’S WAR NOVELSOld Man’s WarThe Ghost BrigadesThe Last ColonyZoë’s TaleThe Human DivisionThe End of All ThingsTHE LOCK IN SERIESLock InHead OnUnlockedTHE INTERDEPENDENCY SEQUENCEThe Collapsing EmpireThe Consuming FireThe Last EmperoxEDITED BY JOHN SCALZIMetatropolisAt the Publisher's request, this title is being sold without Digital Rights Management Software (DRM) applied.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: The Consu are back. Gretchen & her Obin assistant Ran have their hands full!
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Shattering Peace is the seventh book in the Old Man's War series. Book one came out twenty years ago in 2005. I would strongly recommend that you read the first six books before Shattering Peace.Gretchen, the protagonist of Shattering Peace, tells us that she was Zoe Perry's best friend. I remember John Perry (the original protagonist), his wife Jane Sagan, and their adopted daughter Zoe. I don't recall Gretchen but that's fine. (Gretchen knows her stuff so it doesn't matter how well she knew Zoe.)John Perry was a soldier. Gretchen is a diplomat. We are now at a point where keeping the peace is critical. No one wants war to break out again.Gretchen is summoned to deal with a diplomatic crisis. For this she gets an Obin assistant, Ran.  I particularly enjoyed the Obin Ran. I enjoy well-drawn alien races.The Consu are back, and the first one Gretchen meets is suicidal. The story goes on from there.I found Shattering Peace an immensely enjoyable read. The writing is both smart and snarky. Classic Scalzi. And why I love this series.

bookDescription: We were fighting on the wrong side, of a war we couldn't win. And that was the good news. The Ruhar hit us on Columbus Day. There we were, innocently drifting along the cosmos on our little blue marble, like the native Americans in 1492. Over the horizon come ships of a technologically advanced, aggressive culture, and BAM! There go the good old days, when humans only got killed by each other. So, Columbus Day. It fits. When the morning sky twinkled again, this time with Kristang starships jumping in to hammer the Ruhar, we thought we were saved. The UN Expeditionary Force hitched a ride on Kristang ships to fight the Ruhar, wherever our new allies thought we could be useful. So, I went from fighting with the US Army in Nigeria, to fighting in space. It was lies, all of it. We shouldn't even be fighting the Ruhar, they aren't our enemy, our allies are. I'd better start at the beginning....A selection of scenes from Columbus Day:There was a faint click, and the other door popped open a quarter inch. Cautiously, I pulled it open and stuck my head in. Beyond the door was a warehouse, maybe fifty feet by thirty, twenty feet tall, filled with racks of what I thought was mostly old, useless, dirty, dusty broken junk. I wandered in cautiously. Why the Ruhar had made the effort to store any of it made no sense to me. Surely there had to be something in there that I could use as a weapon.A man’s voice, with a snarky attitude, rang out behind me. “Excellent! Bipedal, 1300cc brain, opposable thumbs. A hairless monkey. You can carry me out of here.”I spun around in a panic. No one was there. “Who said that?”“Me. Here, I’m the shiny cylinder on the shelf. I unlocked that door."“You are? You mean you’re talking to me through a speaker in that thing?”“No, I am that thing. I am what you monkeys call an artificial intelligence.”I cocked my head and examined it skeptically. “You look like a chrome-plated beer can." That was a completely accurate description. The cylinder even tapered slightly at the top, and was ringed by a ridge. "You’re really an AI?""Yup. You should refer to me as The Lord God Almighty.”“That position is already filled. I think I’ll call you Skippy.”“Don’t call me that, it sounds disrespectful, monkey.”“You prefer shithead? Because that’s the other option, Skippy-O.” I kept glancing around, fearing the Ruhar would hear me.“Can we compromise on The Great and Powerful Oz?” It asked.“I’m not a flying monkey, so that’s a no, Skippy.”“Unacceptable.”“How about we go for something more formal, like Skippy McSkippster?”“No.”“Skippy Skipperson? Skippy Skippkowski? Skippy Von Skipping? Or maybe Sir Skippy Skippton-Skippersworth?”“No, no, no and NO!”“I can go on like this all day.”“I believe you could.”"What you got?" Ski asked.Cornpone winked. "Uh, let's see. Damn! I got a gen-u-ine smorgasbord of Hooah! bars.""A smorgasbord?" I asked skeptically. "Really?""Oh yeah, a smorgasbord at least. Could be a plethora, maybe even, oooh, an honest to God, gosh-darned corn-u-copia of snack foods." It was funny to hear Jesse say 'plethora' in his deep southern accent."Cut the bullshit, man, you're making me hungry." Ski protested. "What flavors you got in there?""Well, I got Cinnamon Cardboard, of course, also Raisins 'n' Gravel, and, my personal fave, Original Sawdust."Crap. I got stuck with Raisin 'n' Gravel. The raisins were harder to chew than the gravel.“Space combat sounds complicated.” I thought back to when I’d listened to the Chicken pilot talk about air combat after our first war game, on Camp Alpha.“Uh huh. Then there’s the Skippy factor.”Part of me wanted to avoid taking the bait. “The Skippy factor?”“You know, my incredible awesomeness.”
