bookDescription: The Ghost Brigades are the Special Forces of the Colonial Defense Forces, elite troops created from the DNA of the dead and turned into the perfect soldiers for the CDF's toughest operations. They're young, they're fast and strong, and they're totally without normal human qualms.The universe is a dangerous place for humanity—and it's about to become far more dangerous. Three races that humans have clashed with before have allied to halt our expansion into space. Their linchpin: the turncoat military scientist Charles Boutin, who knows the CDF's biggest military secrets. To prevail, the CDF must find out why Boutin did what he did.Jared Dirac is the only human who can provide answers -- a superhuman hybrid, created from Boutin's DNA, Jared's brain should be able to access Boutin's electronic memories. But when the memory transplant appears to fail, Jared is given to the Ghost Brigades.At first, Jared is a perfect soldier, but as Boutin's memories slowly surface, Jared begins to intuit the reason's for Boutin's betrayal. As Jared desperately hunts for his "father," he must also come to grips with his own choices. Time is running out: The alliance is preparing its offensive, and some of them plan worse things than humanity's mere military defeat…Old Man's War Series #1 Old Man’s War #2 The Ghost Brigades #3 The Last Colony #4 Zoe’s Tale #5 The Human Division #6 The End of All Things  Short fiction: “After the Coup” Other Tor Books The Android’s Dream Agent to the Stars Your Hate Mail Will Be Graded Fuzzy Nation Redshirts Lock In The Collapsing Empire (forthcoming)At the Publisher's request, this title is being sold without Digital Rights Management Software (DRM) applied.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Wonderful follow-up to Old Man's War
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Series Info/Source: This is the second book in the Old Man's War series.  I borrowed this from Kindle Unlimited on audiobook.Thoughts: I enjoyed this but not quite as much as the first book in the series.  I think the wonder of this world and the humor in the first book just really blew me away.  I did enjoy still getting to see Jane, but this story focused  more on a Ghost Brigade soldier (Jared) created from the consciousness of traitor to humanity, Charles Boutin.I continued to enjoy this world and really enjoyed learning more about The Ghost Brigades.  We meet a mostly new set of characters in this book, although Jane and Harry are in and out of the story some.  I enjoyed Jared as a character but not as much as I enjoyed Perry and crew in the first book.We do get a much broader story here about the CDF versus three other alien races.  We also get exposed to some intriguing questions about the CDF and their motives when it comes to human interactions with alien races.  Additionally, this book focuses a lot on The Ghost Brigades themselves and what it really means to be human.I didn't think this was as funny as "Old Man's War" but there is some humor throughout.  I listened to this on audiobook and really enjoyed the audiobook narration.  I would recommend listening to this on audiobook if you enjoy audiobooks.My Summary (4/5):  Overall I liked this.  I didn't think there was as much humor in this book and didn't enjoy the characters in this second book quite as much.  However, I did enjoy learning more about The Ghost Brigades and delving deeper in to this world.  I also really enjoyed the broadened storyline around the CDF and the three alien races joining forces against humanity.  I look forward to reading "The Lost Colony" soon.  I would recommend to those who enjoy science fiction with some intriguing space travel, aliens, and a look into what it means to be human.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I enjoyed the first book in the Old Man's War series and so picked up this one soon after. I enjoyed it as much as the first. productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I'm writing the same review for all of the John Scalzi books that I've read. If you want to know what this book's about, read the description and the sample. I'd only be repeating that info here. What I want you to know is that Scalzi is a genius Writer (with a capital "W"). "Writer" seems so pedestrian when referring to Scalzi. Better to describe him as "Novelist" or "Storyteller" or "Wordmonger" (maybe not that last one). Or "Craftsman." His stories are clever and brilliant, all unique, humorous and dramatic, believable...yet out there. If you want to get your mind off your troubles, or the troubles of the world, or you want to let go of your disbeliefs willingly (like a movie), or you need some frivolity, or you like plot twists and turns, or you think you can guess what's coming next or later in a story (like I do) but you get it totally wrong, or you just want a tale that blows your mind, read one of John Scalzi's books. I guarantee that you will be totally ecstatic, if not downright jubilant. You're welcome.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Exploring Humanity and Identity in "The Ghost Brigades"
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: John Scalzi's "The Ghost Brigades" delves deep into the intricacies of identity and humanity within a futuristic setting, captivating readers with its thought-provoking narrative and dynamic characters. This gripping science fiction novel seamlessly combines action-packed scenes with philosophical musings, earning it a well-deserved five-star rating.Set in a universe where consciousness can be transferred between bodies, the story follows Jared Dirac, a special forces soldier created from the DNA of a deceased traitor. As Jared grapples with his unique origin and struggles to define his own identity, he becomes embroiled in a galactic conflict that threatens the very fabric of humanity.One of the novel's greatest strengths lies in its exploration of identity. Scalzi masterfully examines what it means to be human, posing questions about nature versus nurture and the essence of consciousness. Through Jared's journey of self-discovery, readers are prompted to reflect on their own perceptions of identity and the factors that shape individuality.The character development in "The Ghost Brigades" is exemplary. Each member of the Ghost Brigade, despite being genetically engineered, possesses distinct personalities and motivations. From the enigmatic Jane Sagan to the morally conflicted Charles Boutin, every character adds depth to the narrative, drawing readers further into the story's intricacies.Scalzi's world-building is equally impressive, immersing readers in a future where humanity has colonized distant planets and formed alliances with alien species. The political intrigue and interstellar conflicts add layers of complexity to the plot, keeping readers on the edge of their seats with each twist and turn.While the novel is replete with thrilling action sequences, Scalzi also explores deeper themes such as ethics, loyalty, and the consequences of technological advancement. He deftly balances these weighty topics with moments of humor and introspection, ensuring that "The Ghost Brigades" appeals to a wide range of readers.Moreover, Scalzi's prose is engaging and accessible, making the complex concepts within the story easily digestible without sacrificing depth. His sharp wit and clever dialogue inject energy into the narrative, driving the plot forward at a relentless pace."The Ghost Brigades" is more than just a sci-fi adventure; it is a meditation on the human condition and our place in the universe. Scalzi's masterful storytelling forces readers to confront their own beliefs and prejudices, challenging them to consider the implications of scientific progress on society.In conclusion, "The Ghost Brigades" is a tour de force of science fiction literature, deserving of its five-star rating. With its compelling characters, thought-provoking themes, and gripping plot, this novel is sure to leave a lasting impression on readers long after they have turned the final page. Scalzi has crafted a masterpiece that transcends genre boundaries, earning its place among the classics of speculative fiction.

bookDescription:
The Iron Lady has met her match.
Lieutenant Colonel Arthur Hanson and the CSV Margaret Thatcher welcome reinforcements to the Orion Spur. Though it’s not a heavy-hitting battlegroup, the light carriers and support vessels sailing through the wormhole are sufficient firepower to handle what’s left of the terrorists.
But overconfidence is their undoing.
League-made heavy battle cruisers strike without warning and decimate the new arrivals, obliterating an unarmed hospital ship in the surprise attack. Arthur isn’t the only one who sees red as horrific losses pile up, the enemy seeming to anticipate their every FTL jump. With President Robbins refusing to send overwhelming force to end the conflict quickly, desperation drives Arthur to use any means necessary to gain intel from their war captive.
And threats of mutiny once again gain steam.
Intelligence collected under duress proves ineffective, while looming court martial brings Arthur to the breaking point. But it will take more than a crisis of conscience to see the conflict through to the bitter end against a dominating force.
It will take an iron will.

aPlusContent.title: From the Publisher
aPlusContent.rawText:
From the Publisher
The Iron Lady has met her match. 
Lieutenant Colonel Arthur Hanson and the CSV Margaret Thatcher welcome reinforcements to the Orion Spur. Though it’s not a heavy-hitting battlegroup, the light carriers and support vessels sailing through the wormhole are sufficient firepower to handle what’s left of the insurgents. 
But overconfidence is their undoing. 
League-made heavy battle cruisers strike without warning and decimate the new arrivals, obliterating an unarmed hospital ship in the surprise attack. Arthur isn’t the only one who sees red as horrific losses pile up, the enemy seeming to anticipate their every FTL jump. Desperation drives Arthur to use any means necessary to gain intel from their war captive. 
Intelligence collected under duress proves ineffective, while a looming court martial brings Arthur to the breaking point. But it will take more than a crisis of conscience to see the conflict through to the bitter end against a dominating force. 
It will take an iron will. 
Three more action-packed series are set in the Terran Diaspora Universe: 
Battlegroup Z 
After thirty-five years of peace, one vicious attack destroys it all. An unexpected enemy emerges with an overwhelming force designed to obliterate the Terran Coalition. Reservist Lieutenant Justin Spencer straps into the cockpit, determined to save his home from a vicious foe. 
Even outnumbered and outgunned, Justin is never out of the fight. 
Echoes of War Series 
Colonel David Cohen has sacrificed his dream of becoming a rabbi to help defend his home planet against the oppressive League of Sol. And even as he grapples with the lives lost under his command, David knows failure to defeat this merciless enemy is not an option. If he fails in his mission, billions face enslavement by a ruthless regime. Now it’s an all-out fight for the galaxy’s freedom. 
Because a man's greatest foe lies within. 
The Lost Warship Series 
The war with the League of Sol ended in victory for the Terran Coalition. Major General David Cohen and his crew conclude their three-month goodwill cruise with one final FTL jump. But instead of returning home in a blaze of glory, the wormhole collapses and hurls them more than four million lightyears into the unknown. 
Stranding them in a distant galaxy.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: It’s decent. But the author really needs to get over “snickered” as a substitute for laughing.  It’s very distracting, like a group of teenagers sneaking porn mags and snickering.  •  Merriam-Webster: To laugh in a covert or partly suppressed manner, often with a derisive or mocking tone; a snicker is a “half-suppressed, typically scornful laugh.”•  Oxford English Dictionary: To give a smothered or half-suppressed laugh, often implying slyness, mockery, or amusement at something private or inappropriate.•  Cambridge Dictionary: To laugh quietly in a way that is not open or genuine, often at something unkind or in a sneaky manner.

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: Daniel Gibbs's Iron Fleet series excels in its depiction of space warfare, which remains genuinely compelling throughout. However, certain ideological elements undermined my engagement with the narrative.The pervasive religious nationalism struck me as anachronistic for an interstellar civilization. While Gibbs attempts to present a generalized rather than denominationally specific faith system, the notion that such particularistic, terrestrially-bound ideology would persist as a dominant force among advanced spacefaring societies strains credibility. From a theological perspective, one might expect more universalist or cosmologically-informed spiritual frameworks to emerge in such a context.Similarly, the Cold War-era capitalism versus communism framework feels historically myopic. Contemporary geopolitical realities reveal a more complex picture, particularly China's hybrid model of market economics within centralized governance. Against this backdrop, the premise of a resurgent Soviet-style communist empire expanding into space reads as dated political science fiction rather than plausible extrapolation.These conceptual limitations aside, readers seeking well-executed space combat sequences will find much to appreciate in the Iron Fleet series. The tactical elements are thoughtfully rendered, even if the broader ideological and moralistic architecture of Gibbs's universe lacks sophistication.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Well written.  Good book.  Doesn't mean I'll read the rest.
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: The pacing is reasonably fast and the characters are pretty well developed.  The writing is good with few errors to give you pause.Years ago a famous writer told me that it is difficult to keep a story arc going for more than three books.  I'd like to say he was wrong (and he has substantially exceeded that 3-book arc) but most of the time I don't think he is.So it's still a very good book but after 6 books in the arc I'm just done.  It isn't the fault of the writer, I just don't have the patience or care enough to bother reading more of these books.  I find myself tiring of what increasingly feels like filler and I'm increasingly irritated when an author tells me what the hero/heroine sees in the eyes of another (especially in an alien which should have different visible tells).I find myself skipping significant portions of the books which are supposedly displaying the incredible insights and even good portions of action sequences because I'm not finding them new or interesting.I will likely read more from this very skilled writer - but not in this story arc.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I’ve enjoyed the story so far. The books have been well written and edited. The story fast paced.The only problem I have with the story is the story’s timeline. I think that the timeline in the story is too fast paced. It seems like the characters in the story don’t really have any time to eat, sleep and visit the lavatory. It’s like one ever after the other happens is so short a period that the characters can’t catch a breath. The main character in the story just goes bulldozing from one event after another and relying on hope to see it through. There does not seem to be any effort to study the enemy and come up with counters and think the situation through before acting.

bookDescription: The war against the AI was won but a new threat is rising. Hank Spears is content with his life as a scrapper until he unearths an artificial intelligence who warns him of a grave threat to all life in the universe. Since AI has long been outlawed and anyone caught harboring one is imprisoned or executed, the two must go on the run, fleeing into the far reaches of space.They must avoid capture, all for the sake of those who would imprison them.Looking for help from old friends to fight new enemies, Hank must find a way to save himself so that he can save the universe.Can this simple scrapper become the hero the universe needs before it’s too late?Find out in Star Scrapper, the thrilling new science fiction series from USA Today Bestselling Author J.N. Chaney and Matthew A. Goodwin.

bookDescription: The wrong crew. The wrong ship. The right Captain.Idealistic navy lieutenant Jacob Grimm just wanted to honor his mother’s sacrifice in the last great war. When he’s forced to return fire and destroy a squadron of ships to save his own, he thinks he’s the hero…Until they discover the ships are full of children.Disgraced and denied promotion, Jacob’s career is over. That is until the head of ONI needs a disposable officer to command a battered destroyer on the rim.There’s just one problem, Interceptor hasn’t had a CO in months and the ship is a mess. Worse, the system he’s assigned to is corrupt and on the verge of all-out civil war with the Alliance.However, no one told Jacob he was disposable.Pirates, smugglers, and Caliphate spies complicate the situation and one captain with an old ship can’t enforce the law, let alone stop anyone.The single greatest discovery of all time is about to change intergalactic politics forever. If Jacob doesn’t find a way to succeed, then it won’t just be the end of the Alliance, it will be the end of freedom for humanity. From USA Today bestselling author Jeffery H. Haskell comes a military science fiction epic in the tradition of Honor Harrington and Star Trek. If you love heroes and starships, you will love to stand with Commander Jacob T. Grimm Against all Odds. You’re in the Navy now!"Against All Odds is classic space fleet military science fiction in the tradition of David Weber, with memorable characters and thrilling action. Haskell is a new shining star in the genre." --Rick Partlow, author of Contact Front

aPlusContent.title: From the Publisher
aPlusContent.rawText:
From the Publisher
The wrong crew. The wrong ship. The right Captain. 
Disgraced and denied promotion, Jacob’s career is over. That is until the head of ONI needs a disposable officer to command a battered destroyer on the rim. 
There’s just one problem, Interceptor hasn’t had a CO in months and the ship is a mess. Worse, the system he’s assigned to is corrupt and on the verge of all-out civil war with the Alliance. 
However, no one told Jacob he was disposable. 
Pirates, smugglers, and Caliphate spies complicate the situation and one captain with an old ship can’t enforce the law, let alone stop anyone. 
The single greatest discovery of all time is about to change intergalactic politics forever. If Jacob doesn’t find a way to succeed, then it won’t just be the end of the Alliance, it will be the end of freedom for humanity. 
"Classic space fleet military science fiction in the tradition of David Weber." — Rick Partlow, author of Contact Front 
A New Classic in Mil SF! 
"Compulsively readable and delightfully original. It's classic science fiction for today's reader: a brutal, smart, fast-paced adventure."—Rachel Aukes, author of Space Troopers 
Detailed Military Action. 
"Jeffery H. Haskell introduces a detailed world that feels so real from page one all the way to its epic ending."—Jonathan Yanez, author Forsaken Mercenary 
Gritty and Heartfelt! 
"Against All Odds is both gritty and heartfelt, both action-packed and character-driven. Fans of military science fiction will love it."—Daniel Arenson, USA Today author of Starship Freedom 
Heroes and Starships. 
"Best author with his fly down,"—Larry Correia, author of Monster Hunter International.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I’m so into these characters now! Wow! Really great writing by this author. The characters are developed really well throughout this book. I can only imagine how that will expand. It was truly heartwarming, and I gotta say, honorable how Grimm pulled that boat and it’s team together. They became a real fighting machine. When a crew acts in the he way that these do then you know their leader is a good one, who inspires them to be their best, to be the best the Navy and the Marines the military has to offer.The other portion of the book is sickening in its realism of disgusting, deceitful, dishonest, stab you in the back cowardly and traitorous characters. The things human beings are capable of inflicting upon others in the name of power, money, country or religion is just pathetic. But it’s not fiction in our real world, as we all know, and this book gives a heavy dose of evil; believable fiction and so disgusting and heartbreaking for that true fact of the semblance of possibilities. 😢The other thing this author is really good at is battle scenes and there’s multiples of them—against different ships, locations, marines battles, and we even get battles from the enemies perspective. So not a dull moment.I’m so excited I found this series & I was eager to start as I’ve read this author before and knew I wouldn’t be disappointed. Hoo yah!
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on May 16, 2024

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Honor Harrington Meets James T. Kirk
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: There’s a lot of very good military sci-fi series out there. The genre has several niches; ground combat, space combat, political space opera, etc. I tend to favor ground combat books, but I am a big David Weber (Honor Harrington) fan, so I decided to jump in with Jeffery Haskell’s Against All Odds, the first book of the Grimm’s War series.The first chapter is a gut punch. You start out with a young, up-and-coming James T. Kirk-esque officer. In a brilliant feat of writing, Haskell introduces an almost insurmountable flaw to the character in the most dramatic fashion possible. I was hooked from that point on.This isn’t a hero that can do no wrong. His career ends up in the proverbial toilet. He’s given a ship, but it’s a far cry from the flagship of the fleet. In fact, it is an old tiny destroyer, one without its primary drive. Its captain is dead and its crew has been idling on a backwater world, watching their careers pass them by. So much for my initial thoughts of James Kirk.Haskell brings in a layer of politics, weaves in an intriguing mystery, and provides his protagonist with a chance to achieve some level of redemption…not just for himself, but for his crew.The Grimm’s War series now has eclipsed Honor Harrington for me. Don’t get me wrong, I love David Weber’s work, but there is a lot of overburden with his brand universe building. That’s not bad, but it does kill the pace and let’s face it, military sci-fi guys love action and battle. Haskell swiftly navigates past things that might slow the plot down, blazing a fast-paced and exciting trail through the stars. He’s produced a series that transcends universe building and focuses on some well-rounded, very human characters.For fans waiting for their next Weber fix, I highly recommend you hop aboard the USS Interceptor and buckle in tight, it’s destined to be a bumpy ride.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2023

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: A story of perseverance and devotion to duty “against all odds”.
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This is a story of young space naval officer who perseveres in doing his duty even after being wrongly blamed for “butchering” kids during a battle in which his fleet was attacked and he not only saved his own ship but minimized the damage to the rest of his fleet and destroyed the attackers’ fleet only to learn afterwards that the “enemy” combatants were children.  While not officially charged, he is crucified by the media and the result is that his career is going nowhere.  He’s reassigned to command an old inoperable space destroyer which he manages thru excellent command decisions to resurrect and break up a human trafficking operation and stop an invasion.  The author spins a great story with well-developed characters, constant action, space battles, a beginning romance, and concludes with a generally happy ending while setting up the situation for the next book in the sequel which I’m looking forward to.  I’m happy to recommend this book.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Great story telling, lots of plot holes
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: If you want a fun space opera with a lot of action, this story is for you.  If you nitpick every detail and plot holes five you nuts this might not be for you.There is too much coincidence, the timing is too tight on every major event, and the decisions made by too many actors are just not in character (why the heck would the pirate captain Duval? Just roll over for the caliphate, he has his money, his ship, and an escape plan, doing whatever the caliphate dude said is not in character, especially if he's worried about his crew rebelling, that last fight would've never happened.  Speaking if which, why did the caliphate set it up like that anyways?  They would've just crewed it themselves. If they wanted deniability they wouldn't have been inslthe stem as heavily as they were!)In General a fun ride with some work needed on it.  I look forward to trying the next novel I. Hopes the author improves as he continues to write.

bookDescription: “I realized that I wasn't going to get any sleep (Just one more page... Just one more page…) I'm not just reading words on a page, I'm there… A hell of a ride.” NetGalley reviewer ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐Humanity is on the brink of annihilation. Only one man can turn the tide.For centuries, we explored the stars and settled new worlds. But a mysterious alien threat emerged, launching devastating attacks and seizing entire star systems. Every fifty years they come, silent and relentless, before disappearing again into the dark. And as they close in on humanity’s home worlds, one more defeat could mean total extinction.Captain Jim Garrett joined the navy to fight back. But when a delicate mission ends in madness and mutiny, Garrett takes the blame and his career is left in ruins.Now, the only thing he commands is a construction site. The CNS Surprise is an experimental warship, half built in the dockyards of Midway Station. Garrett knows the ship inside out, but the navy brass would never let him take the helm, let alone lead her in battle.But when the aliens strike early, with unexpected ferocity, it’s clear that every ship in the fleet will be needed. And the Surprise could be the only hope of slowing the enemy onslaught.Garrett is thrust into command for the first time, launching straight into combat. He must unite a maverick crew and master new technologies, as he leads a desperate counterstrike that will decide mankind’s future.Off Midway Station is a military SF adventure of high-stakes space warfare, nail-biting action, and characters you would gladly follow into battle. A monumental journey of courage, innovation, and the relentless pursuit of survival, it’s perfect for fans of Jack Campbell, David Weber, and Marko Kloos.See why readers love Marc Alan Edelheit’s epic stories of battle and adventure:“Cutting edge… A wild ride that ended in truly epic fashion… I absolutely enjoyed it from start to finish… AMAZING.” FanFiAddict ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐“Wow!… fast-paced… action packed adventure! Wild, exciting, gripping!” Goodreads reviewer ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐“Holy cow!… awesome… A page turner… I stayed up way too late reading this.” Goodreads reviewer ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐“Absolutely epic… gripping… I thoroughly recommend this!” Goodreads reviewer ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐“Your adrenaline will be pumping…Your blood pressure will rise… you will find hard to put down.” NetGalley reviewer ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐“Edelheit belongs amongst the elite … It is difficult to put the book down… By the end, it is nearly impossible… You need to pick up a copy!” Goodreads reviewer ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐“Outstanding! I couldn't put it down. Intense action.” Goodreads reviewer ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐“A must-read… clear your calendar and hold on for the ride!” Goodreads reviewer ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Largely a one character story with a lot of nuisance. This story offers a lot of scifi to unpack. I found the  Character development satisfying.  Flawed leaders, over achieving crew, real life drama.  War is not pretty. A good read!
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Off Midway starts off with a tense action scene and then cools down for a considerable period. First novels in a series can be slow because of the world building involved. Off Midway though suffers from a lot of detail that adds nothing. For example, the leader of a group of starfighters goes through systems checks. Edelheit describes in excruciating detail every check the officer goes through. This leads to paragraphs when a sentence would have sufficed. Off Midway also suffers from repetitive loops of dialogue and narrative. Edelheit needs to edit his work to pare down these loops. The novel does pick up toward the end proving that Edelheit is capable of producing suspenseful action. My advice would be to skip over the minutae and get to the good part. I'm willing to read the next book in the series to see where it goes.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I have read all of Marks Stiger series novels. Thouroghly enjoyed them and had purposely avoided this new approach.  My mistake.  The action is amazing in its own right but the layout of the technology, space travel, weapons systems, an entirely new world in 200 pages or less and keep the storyline flowing was nothing short of remarkable.  The second half of the book was classic Edelheit, action to the umpteenth degree.  Twists and turns galore.  If you were like me and read the other books but avoided these new books.  Read this one first. I promise you won't be disappointed.  Excellent job Mark.  Thank you !
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This book is well written and totally engaging.  Hopefully, the "Guardians of the Dark" series will have a book #2 soon.The main character suffered a major hit to his spaceforce career when he was forced to make a difficult decision during a battle, which was later vindicated; however, he became blackballed from future command opportunities.  Being a highly competent professional, he proved outstanding in an alternative career path, but his dream to command a ship never died.  During a sneak attack by humanity's enemy, Captain Garrett was in the right place, at the right time to assume command of a new ship under construction.  From this moment, he proves he was not only at the right place at the right time but also the perfect captain for the ship.This book ends as a cliffhanger and ready for book #2.  I first read this as a borrowed book and immediately purchased it upon finishing it (the first time).  Hopefully, Marc Edelheit doesn't keep me hanging for book #2.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on March 7, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Midway Station is a vast shipyard and fleet staging area, our Captain Garrett is stationed here as a "Job" Captain, meaning the Job is the construction and commissioning of a new warship. His latest project is known as a Mothership. Designed to carry both military and science personnel, while operating deep in hostile territory, and she's nearing completion.The action begins on the first page, and while it tapers off enough to catch a breath, it doesn't let up for long. There's a point where I realized that I wasn't going to get any sleep (just one more page... just one more page).As a sailor in the USN, and an Airedale, there was plenty to love here too. The Mothership has her own recently assigned air (space?) contingent, and they will be needing to earn their keep (even though the ship isn't really complete). When describing the Mothership's interior, the hangar spaces, the sights and sounds of the flight deck, I'm not just reading words on a page... I'm there. Watching flight ops. Watching the Marine Detachment jog. Bumping my shoulder on a frame of the ship as I move by someone in the passageway.  Procedures too... there's a lot of checklists when working on aircraft, there was some déjà vu moments that brought me back to my younger days.This is some great military science fiction. If you are a fan of the genre, then there's something here for you. It's a hell of a ride.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2024

Sorry if I missed this info in the read.  This story reminds me of  the Grimm series of space navy stuff.  Which I can't put down.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Not too bad. Some interesting ideas and plot lines here. The biggest thing that turned me off was that it was just too wordy. I think the author could significantly pare down the word content and make things flow a lot better. Using repeated adjectives that essentially describe the same thing, characters continually reflecting on the situation, as though to sum up the last few pages of description. Paragraphs describing the gravity of the mood in the room. Even the characters often speak in duplicate, saying two sentences that are essentially the same, as though the author couldn’t decide which to use. I actually started hating the word ‘and’ about halfway through the book. One of the old writing adages is ‘show, don’t tell’. The author seems to want to both show and tell the same things repeatedly.Again, not a bad tale but the writing style was a bit off-putting for me personally. It kept jarring me out of the story and preventing any sort of immersion. Hopefully the author will see this as constructive feedback for future books.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on December 31, 2024

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: A good read except for the lack of a good ending
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: Decent read, space battle novels are my thing and the story was entertaining enough. The author gets a bit excessively descriptive at times but fortunately its not overwhelming and relatively easy to skip ahead to the important stuff if you don't care what colour the eyebrows are on a character. Its not quite as technical as other books of this genre so if you like your SciFi with a bit less Sci and more Fi this mostly fits the bill. My only con for this story is that the ending was somewhat unfulfilling. I know this is intended to be a book series so the story will continue, but other similar book series I've read at least provide a satisfactory ending for each book, this book didn't really have an ending per se, just a basic pause point. Its more "part 1" than "book 1". But I will read the book 2 when it comes out.

bookDescription:
Thomas and his crew face their most dangerous quest yet. Morgana's forces are searching for something ancient and powerful, and they need to get there first.
Some boundaries were never meant to be crossed.
The Wastes—a cosmic dead zone where sensors can’t be trusted and those who enter rarely return. As Excalibur ventures into this treacherous domain, Thomas must navigate not only the physical dangers but also mysteries that have remained hidden since long before Arthur's time.
With Turquine in relentless pursuit and tensions mounting among allies pushed to their limits, Thomas and his crew must rely on every skill, every resource, and every bond they've forged to survive.
What they discover could change everything.

bookDescription: Reformed, repackaged, and re-engineered, the Stillness reveal that they never went away.They merely waited. Watching. Planning.And those plans will collide with the rising stars of an empire based on justice and action. Out in the deep black, Abel Tudor and his crew will fight to prove that command isn't given, it's earned—and their parents chose well, giving them the helm to a warship that could change history with one fateful journey.But they have allies who are proven veterans of a galaxy gone mad with violence. Van, Torina, and the crew aren’t retiring—they’re reloading, and with the Fafnir and crew come something the Stillness have never faced before.Van Tudor, the commander of it all. He’s older, wiser, and unwavering in his commitment to justice, but now, he’s got decades of experience in the trenches with his friends, family, and allies who share his vision for freedom and peace—at any cost.Along the way, Van, Abel, and their teams will meet old friends, new enemies, and discover that space isn't just crowded—It can be lethal.Especially for the young, no matter who their parents are.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This story was supposed to end a couple of books ago, but I am really glad it did not.  The new Enemy is the Stillness and they are pulling no punches.  Van and his team need to come up with a way to fight them because they are fighting dirty.  Also, their children are not off limits.This is a well crafted story that keeps you interested from start to finish.  The introduction of new characters, Van’s, Funboy’s, Iky’s and Mandaville’s kids is excellent.  Keep the stories coming.

Even worse, a Hegemony fleet is lurking in the system. productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Marc Alan Edelheit has done it again!!
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Marc is a great storyteller of military intrigue. In his newest space adventure he chronicles the maiden mission of the Unions newest Starship Ranger, and her newly appointed Captain Jason Steele. Captain Steele finds himself in the middle of military coup, but he must make a Command Decision that will put his crew in harm's way that just might save the Unions fleet. For those of us that were raised on WWII movies Marc captures this new age submarine type of thriller. Fast paced and action packed from start to finish. Outstanding read!!!

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I have read every one of Marc's books and enjoyed them all. However, this book was slow and just plodded along. bookDescription:
Mack Banes is the first face you want to see in the last place you'd want to be…
Wreck Jumpers are highly specialized soldiers trained for search and rescue deep behind enemy lines. They are the special forces operators sent in when things have already gone from bad to worse.
Malcolm "Mack" Baines and his Recovery Team are the best of the best. When a Special Orbital Assault Regiment School nestled inside an asteroid belt suddenly goes dark, Mack and his team of Wreck Jumpers are tasked with putting eyes on the target.
Their mission: recon the site and turn the comms back on.
What they find is a base in chaos with survivors desperately holding out for rescue amid oceans of floating rock and an unknown enemy determined to make the Wreck Jumpers part of a growing body count.
Just one wrong move could mean a crushing end in the cold vacuum of space and the death of everyone relying on Mack and his operators…
But that's why Mack became a Wreck Jumper in the first place.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: This is not your normal scifi...  this is Wreck Jumpers.... modeled after Para rescue.
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Wreck Jumpers.If you pick this up and have no idea of the Galaxy Edge universe, this is a great teaser to get ALL of them.  This book was modeled after some of the most unsung heroes who do not want the accolades, who do not want the fame.  ParaRescue(PR). Most military knows now that Doc, is ..DOC.  Doc must be protected at all costs, however, PR's bring a whole new level of kick ass to the field.  When the US Special Forces calls for medivac, PR comes in and kicks more ass than the SF kids, to get the wounded out and safe.Why is this important?  Why do I put an emphasis on this level of effort?  Ask a military friend you know.  PR are the guys who JUMP INTO the areas that are so hot the SF teams need an evac, they are the fearless, only GOD will stop them from succeeding at whatever mission is in front of them.  Black holes?  bah, trivial crap.  The enlisted are the key drivers of the REC-teams.  You want something done?  Give it to the First Sargent and tell him the teams can have the rest of the day off when finished.  You won't get the order completed before it's done. There is a constant in any military, the Senior Enlisted are the backbone, and the officers, if they are smart will listen to them.  Remember that as you read forward.I thought this would be a "Oh? crap broke? let's go get it and save folks and do some heroic stuff" type of read, maybe in the first few paragraphs but it takes that and expands it into the Galaxy Edge universe, it shows the growth and mentoring of the enlisted characters in intense situations and allows you to put a real voice into your head when you read the lines.  There is the new guy who has to earn his place and keep it, the old salt running the team, who feels like he has a PhD in warfighting. and the Officers, who have all built something that this type of team must have.  Implicit trust in the team, each other, and doing the right thing, even if it will cause problems.Standard military, cover your ass is one thing, but in this Universe it carries to a whole new level.I apply voices to each character as I read, a voice, an image and a manner of body language.  Fresher, the new guy has this just out of puberty voice in my head that still breaks when he gets excited.  Top (Mack) has a voice similar to a 80's Scifi TV show Admiral, and Creeper?  His voice is one of the pilots off that same series.  yeah, corny as hell but.. it's how I read.The story is enveloping, enticing and absolutely spot on for this Universe and fits into it like a glove.  For those of you reading this, and not familiar, it is a perfect intro to the Universe and a great lead into Dark Ops, Night Ops and the skills and absolute top tier abilities to go save those and prevent the enemy access to the good stuff.  If you enjoy Scifi, this is a Universe that Jason and Nick and many others over at Wargate spend all their time giving us the ability to escape from the day to day BS we deal with.If you have read into this Universe, gear up, get your get set and your L-comm set for a few hours of seamless matching and some hair raising rescues and plots.This book has some really awesome plot slides and twists, and will keep you in it  cover to cover.  Get into Wreck Jumpers and get to reading.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on July 29, 2025

bookDescription: When a running battle brings the Fafnir home to earth, it ends with the death of a trusted friend—and a new focus on what comes next for Van and his crew.The Guild is rotten. It must be changed. It must be healed. But to do that, Van will have to marshal resources on a scale he's never considered, and that means calling in favors from friends.With the Schegith fleet in training, and the Conoku itching to get back into the fight, Van has a clear plan for what he has to do—which is the one thing he doesn't want to do.The time for war is here. The time for change is now.A new leader is needed, and Van will discover if he can take control of Yotov's criminal empire—and save the victims across known space.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: The main characters of the Fafnir and their associated ‘friendlies’ / associated ‘good guys’, protecting and fighting on behalf of innocents and well deserving institutions and planets, are the most entertaining group of beings in addition to their AI advanced almost human companions, are a never ending, yet consistently individual characters assembled throughout the universe. It is the good guys against the worst guys, with all the unexpected ups and downs in imaginative situations. I thoroughly enjoy being entertained by the antics of the various characters and constantly new situations they rally to correct, improve or assist. There is plenty of humor, compassion, dedication, aggression and good vibes to keep you reading, without even mentioning the advanced technologies of all kinds. If you want to enjoy a nail biting, action packed series expertly feathered with both the good and bad guys, in ways not easily imagined, but artfully described, then this series is an absolute must. You will be constantly entertained and happy to have read each and every book!

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: There's nothing "backyard" about The Backyard Starship series
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I'm a five decade scifi novel enthusiast. From Isaac Asimov to Roger Zelazny, it's been my favorite genre since I started reading in grade school, where I found Madeleine L'Engle "A Wrinkle in Time".Today, J. N. Chaney & his co-authors of a variety of scifi series, take up a lot of my reading time.It couldn't be better spent. But for my money, The Backyard Starship is the best of Chaney's work. Even after 22 novels, there is nothing stale about the characters or the story arc.If you only read 1 science fiction series this year, choose The Backyard Starship. I plan to re-read the entire series this coming winter.Get to know Van, Torina, Perry, Netty, Netty-P, Icky, Rob, Gabby, Funboy and The Fafnir, start with book #1 and sooner than you think , you'll have read them all!

bookDescription: The Secession War has begun. A hundred Rim worlds have broken free of the Human Republic’s tyranny. Now they must fight to keep their newfound freedom.The Republic Senate will never tolerate rebellion. An invasion fleet is gathering—vast enough to crush every secessionist world. But to reach the Rim, it must stretch out its supply lines across the stars. This weakness is the rebels’ only hope.Captain Caleb Hawthorne and a handful of warships stand against the Republic Navy’s might. Outnumbered and outgunned, they must strike fast and strike hard, or face annihilation when the fleet reaches their homes.Meanwhile, deep in the Core, Rebecca Guzman risks everything to uncover the Republic’s darkest secrets. What she finds could alter the course of the war—and shake the Republic to its very heart.Fires of Freedom is the explosive second novel of the Secession War series, where the rebellion burns brighter—and the cost of liberty grows ever higher.

bookDescription: I just wanted to tell my neighbor to shut up.My name is Jake Taylor, and I write romance novels. Well, I used to, anyway, before the camping trip where the Grays snatched me. I’m not sure what they wanted with me, but before they could sell me off, I was rescued by a group of mercenaries.Unfortunately, I couldn’t pay for a flight back to Earth. It’s not part of the Galactic Consortium, so there aren’t a lot of flights going there, and most of them are by races that are stealing the Earth’s resources and fomenting discord so that we never get invited into the Consortium.But when I'm offered a chance to join the mercenary company that rescued me, I see my chance to not only make it back to Earth, but also to kick those alien assholes off planet once and for all.They think Earth is their plaything, but I’m going to show them just how wrong they are!For fans of Reluctant Emissary, Psyker Marine, Drone Ensign, and other military LitRPG science fiction.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: This is an entertaining read, and I suspect also a hoot to write.
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: On occasion, I find a book that radiates that it was fun to write.  This is one such.  It was also a hoot to read.  It’s basically a level-up game where the main character starts with an accident or other incident and finds themselves embroiled in a situation where they have to start from the bottom and work their way up to some abilities and save themselves.  This one isn’t different on that level, but clearly, humor is thrown in along the way.  It’s a quick read and easy to submerge oneself in.  There is a good balance between showing the various stats and having the characters discuss them.  The one drawback is common to all such level-up tales.  The oft-referred-to level-up chart appears regularly whenever the character looks at their stats.  Not so much an issue in the text as the reader can see the entire list in one glance and see the improvements, but when confronted in audio, one must listen to a near-endless drone of stats.  The stats in this text are not endless, not displayed at every turn, and are discussed between the characters, so I suspect they will translate better to audio.  Whether you’re an eager reader of these game-like tales or an infrequent visitor to this genre, I recommend this one to all.  You’ll enjoy it from start to finish.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: So, SciFi LitRPG is a thing now
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This is the first LitRPG book I've read. I get the concept, but I was not certain I'd like it. This book hits the mark for being "crunchy" enough with the stat blocks, but not overwhelming. Chris built a world where the crunchy bits actually make sense and don't feel like they're bolted on to "make it LitRPG".It's a bit of a slow start as we're introduced to Jack's new life and he has to level up from romantasy author to mercenary. The struggle is real and Jack has to learn things the hard way. By the end, I was interested to see where this is going. Jack has grown and he's got one huge goal motivating him - kick out the aliens on Earth that created this whole mess for him!

bookDescription: WINNER OF THE JAMES HERBERT AWARD FOR HORROR WRITING “The Troop scared the hell out of me, and I couldn’t put it down. This is old-school horror at its best.” —Stephen KingOnce every year, Scoutmaster Tim Riggs leads a troop of boys into the Canadian wilderness for a weekend camping trip—a tradition as comforting and reliable as a good ghost story around a roaring bonfire. But when an unexpected intruder stumbles upon their campsite—shockingly thin, disturbingly pale, and voraciously hungry—Tim and the boys are exposed to something far more frightening than any tale of terror. The human carrier of a bioengineered nightmare. A horror that spreads faster than fear. A harrowing struggle for survival with no escape from the elements, the infected…or one another.  Part Lord of the Flies, part 28 Days Later—and all-consuming—this tightly written, edge-of-your-seat thriller takes you deep into the heart of darkness, where fear feeds on sanity…and terror hungers for more.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Come for the Gore, Stay for the Character
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Nick Cutter’s The Troop is one of the most viscerally disturbing novels I’ve ever read, and I say that as someone who is not easily rattled. I usually pride myself on having a strong stomach when it comes to horror fiction, but the grotesque imagery in this book genuinely made my skin crawl. Cutter’s descriptions are so vivid, so unapologetically graphic, that I found myself wincing more than once. This isn’t horror that tiptoes around the macabre; it dives in headfirst and drags you with it.What makes The Troop more than just a body horror freak show, however, is the character development. Each of the boys at the center of the story is carefully crafted and complex. As the horrifying events unfold, their personalities are peeled back, layer by layer, sometimes subtly, sometimes violently. Revealing the best and worst of human nature under extreme pressure.You don’t just witness their fear, you feel it. You don’t just observe their unraveling, you understand it. The psychological depth Cutter gives each character adds an emotional weight that elevates the story far above the typical survival horror genre. Their transformations are not only believable but also tragically inevitable, which makes the ending all the more impactful.The Troop is raw, relentless, and utterly unforgettable. It’s a masterclass in body horror, but even more impressively, it’s a study in character and the fragility of morality when pushed to its limits.

Not sure why some are reading horror or true crime if that is their gripe.Anyways, a really solid book that is well executed, it just didn't floor me or become exceptional. That is what it takes to get to a 4.75 or 5 for me.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: As a part-time online book reviewer and fulltime editor, I am constantly on the search for talented new faces in the literature world. After hearing about two up-and-coming novels, I am Murphy's Law by C. E. Scott and "The Troop" by Nick Cutter, I decided to check them out, and I instantly understood what all the buzz was about."The Troop" is classic pulp and gore horror at its very finest. Take an isolated island, five incoherent boy scouts and their somewhat inapt leader, a stranger who suddenly appears out of nowhere with a deadly parasite consuming his body, and you have yourself an unmerciful tale that takes hold of your fear and doesn't let go"The Troop" doesn't read like a book from a new author at all. It was more like a novel written by a seasoned veteran in the field, and I was taken back to the first time I read Carrie as I raced through its pages. I swear, if one of the boys possessed psychic abilities, I would have bet my salary that it was written by Stephen King under a pseudonym. But nope, no Richard Bachman here.The bioengineered tapeworm in this novel is the perfect killing machine. It not only wastes away a person in a matter of hours, but it also alters their thinking process, making the person make rash and tactless decisions (which leads the characters into a horrible downward spiral). It also spreads like no other contagion, through blood, saliva, other bodily fluids, and coughing, and if I was on the island, I would not touch anything that had even been near one of the contaminated. I would have taken my chances and swam through the icy waters surrounding the island, just to be as far away from it as I could.What makes the situation even worse is that after the boys' leadership is all but gone, it is up to the younger counterparts to govern themselves while fighting against the contagion at the same time (this is where the" Lord of the Flies" reference comes into play). At first, you view these boys as the typical stereotypes, the nerd, the bully, the outcast, etc., but some seriously dark psychological issues that weren't known to each other emerge, and the hierarchy completely unravels. What were once the weak become the powerful, and it sets forth some really epic battles within their crew. It is amazing what these adolescents can actually do to each other, and it is particularly frightening to what acts one of the boys is capable of. (I won't give any spoilers. You'll find out for yourself.)All in all, it was an excellent book, and if you are a fan of horror, you will love it. I enjoyed the way he used official documents and other written articles to change the story's pace and give insight to where the parasite originated and what was happening around the island during the characters' peril. I do have a few qualms, but they are hardly negative by any means. Cutter's writing style is immaculate. He has a very keen sense for description, whether when dealing with emotions, the scenery, or the gore, itself, and his prose is majestic in a way, like what you find in British literature. There were times when I would get lost in his prose and have to reread sections because I lost cognition of what was happening. The middle section of the book was somewhat slow, and there was possibly too much backstory. Some people might gripe about this, but I enjoy seeing what makes a character tick. I also viewed some of the character's decision making as unrealistic, but who can say what people will do under such stressful and horrific situations.Be warned, this novel is very graphic in nature, and Cutter describes the horror in ways that make it seem so real. "The Troop" is not for the faint of heart. It is very gory, and like other reviewers have written, there are instances of animal abuse. But it's fiction, people. It didn't really happen, and if you don't like reading about it, don't read it and then give it a bad review. This is a horror novel, after all. It's meant to be disgusting and bring out your emotions, and with that being said, if that's what you're looking for, you've come to the right place.I normally don't write reviews outside of my website, but I couldn't resist after reading these novels. I have placed Doctor Sleep: A Novel, The Troop, and I am Murphy's Law as the top horror reads for 2014. If you're looking for a great read from either one of the big boys on the block or one of the new kids on the block, you can't go wrong with any of the three.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on March 4, 2014

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: The Troop is a really disgusting book. That is a compliment. There were places where I wanted to stop reading, for it to just go away, but I couldn't help myself: I had to know what was going to happen.The plot begins with simple ingenuity: a troop of boy scouts are trapped on an island where something is going terribly wrong and they must battle an unspeakable horror. And then it is ratcheted up: one of the scouts is a budding sadistic psychopath. Think Lord of the Flies meets The Thing meets World War Z meets I Am Legend meets Alien meets Hot Twink Boy Scout Measuring Contest or Scouting for Wood, with a reference to Anne of Green Gables to push it over the top.The combination is delicious, tense and, as I said, disgusting. The plight of the scouts is horrible and rendered in purple but precise prose that reveals author Nick Cutter's day job as literary writer Craig Davidson (though who gets to decide that definition is beyond me). There are pages - particularly concerning a monkey and a kitten in my case - that made me want to shield my eyes. There will be different pages for other people with individual sensibilities: there are lots of horrors and gollops of gore to choose from.There is a thread of homoeroticism that runs throughout The Troop that is just more than subliminal. It is, alas, also confused, as if Cutter was - unbelievably considering what he does splay on the pages - afraid to go there. The only expressed sexuality is arousal by extreme sadism and the phallic nature of the worms give a disturbing contradiction to what Cutter seems to be trying to express. He is far more successful in drawing a direct but subtle line between the callousness of governments and power and the mind of a nascent serial killer. It all comes to fruition with a masterfully done macguffin built into the very structure that is emotionally devastating.But most intriguing is Cutter's repeated theory that there is an innocence in childhood that allows one to withstand terror because one can believe in the unbelievable. He posits that as we reach adulthood we are no longer able to cope with horror or tragedy because we no longer have the ability to imagine it could happen.It is an idea that resonates, gives a melancholy tinge and speaks to Cutter's intentions with what is already a very efficient and great genre novel, and makes the scouts' descent into adulthood and horror all the more affecting and brutal. Any horror fan child, or adult, will enjoy The Troop.Full review at: http://drewrowsome.blogspot.ca/2015/09/the-troop.html
Absolute horror. Fantastic.

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: Old school horror at its finest
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: The scouts of Troop 52 and their Scoutmaster head off to Falstaff Island for a few days of camping with no idea of the horror to come. An emaciated man stumbles into camp begging to be fed, But they don’t realise he is actually very sick or how much of a risk he poses. Who will survive?This is a disturbing read, the body horror is grotesque and nauseating. The breakdown in what is right and wrong, the societal integrity we all think we would uphold, is so well done. It is shocking how the characters adapt to the normality of a world with no rules and discover how quickly they will forsake moral standards to survive.The use of newspaper articles, court transcripts and interviews throughout the book give a glimpse of what’s to come in the story, I liked that. This was Lord of the flies on steroids, the horror is squirming, repulsive and determined, the story is sinister and stomach churning and it is best read when not eating! An old school horror, I loved it, 5 stars

bookDescription: It's all come down to this.A war for control of all civilization, pitting organic life against an ancient evil that knows no fear, no kindness, and no limits.Calamity is loose, and it's been busy learning—from its time with Netty to running wild among the stars, the ultimate evil seeks nothing less than complete dominion over all space and time.And for Calamity, life is in the way.Van and his crew will enlist old friends, new friends, and the very beings he sought to protect from his first days as a rookie Peacemaker, fighting for the dignity of those who had no voices during the dark years of a corrupt guild.It all comes down to this. And one way or another—it all ends here.From the fields of Iowa to deepest space, the final conflict will unfold with only one thing certain: Not everyone will survive, but Van will give his last breath to make certain that when future generations speak his name, they will always remember one fact.Until the end, he gave it all for justice, no matter the cost.

bookDescription:
During a test flight for the world’s first warp engine, Major Noah Gantz is set to go down in the history books.
Despite years of training, the mission goes sideways, and instead of a quick trip to the moon and back, Noah's ship is transported across the universe to stars unknown.
Stranded in space and on the brink of death, Noah is rescued by a sentient starship and its captain. To save his life, the ship’s own biomatter must replace his failing cells.
Now , Noah is different. Stronger, faster… and there’s a voice in his head.
The voice of the ship itself, and its name is Kayan.
With no way to return home, Noah must adapt and rebuild his life in this unfamiliar corner of the universe. And as he does, he discovers a looming threat in the far reaches of space, growing in power, and set on capturing Noah and his ship.
Worse still, this new enemy knows about Earth. . . and it has big plans.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Reminds Me of a TV Show...?
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This is an interesting sci-fi novel, book 1 of a series. It reminds me a lot of a certain TV show, with the characters tweaked enough to avoid copyright, but the plot is different enough that I did read the whole book and purchase Book 2 as well. The POV character, supposedly a top Earth astronaut, comes across as rather immature a lot of the time when I would like to see more quiet confidence and self-esteem, but he's basically a good guy, especially as opposed to the villains we meet. If you're looking for a nice, light read, try this one out.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on July 15, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: A fun ride; parts are familiar but so much is new...
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I'm guessing the author had some inspiration from the TV show "Farscape" as it follows a similar Astronaut-lost-in-space theme. That's not to say "Homeworld Lost" isn't original, because it is, with plenty of interesting twists and turns along the way. I'm particularly fascinated by Kayan. She(?) is a living ship, like Moya from the aforementioned "Farscape," but the author has developed the concept into a unique element of the narrative, with virtually unlimited potential to continue developing as both a character in the story as well as a plot device. I look forward to learning more about her in future books.While I have enjoyed other books by this author, I'm a bit excited by this one, because this novel has the potential to become a massive franchise. While the major plot points could be wrapped up in just one more novel if the author chooses to cut it short, alternatively, it has the chops to be developed into an expanded-universe with numerous books to expand the overall tale. I look forward to reading the next one, and hope more are to come.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2023

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Good, But Doesn't Match Other Series
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: In comparison to the works of a number of authors out there, this would be a four-star book.  However, Mr. Chaney and his various collaborators have so many good series out there (Renegade Stars, Last Hunter, and perhaps one of his best - Backyard Starship and the Peacemaker series) that it's hard not to judge this series in light of those that preceded it.So many of his other series grabbed me early in the book.  I quickly became invested in the main character and knew well before I finished the book that I would be buying the next one in the series.  Not so much with this book.  The overall plot was interesting, but I spend quite a bit of the book wondering if I wanted to continue the series.  I didn't quickly become immersed in this book like I have in the first book of the author's other series, and I certainly didn't become immersed in the main character.Here's a man who's supposed to be one of the very best, considering the mission he was chosen for - smart, talented, and one would assume, trustworthy and a number of other characteristics.  He didn't sell those attributes very well.  He came across as a smart-alecky 15-year-old kid.  He can't even figure out that his many earth-based phrases and colloquialisms don't register with aliens and he's wasting everyone's time by continuing to use (and over-use) them.  You just feel like you want to shake him and tell him to grow up!However, there were enough interesting moments that I have purchased the 2nd book in the series.  I will see how much the character grows.One comment:  I look at the star rating like school grades - 5=A, 4=B, 3=C, 2=D, 1=F.  My rating of 3 starts says I think it's an average book.  I have troubles with people who will rate a book 3 stars but talk about how much they didn't like it and won't continue the series.  That's a 1-star review, or perhaps 2.I like these authors, and the book got a lot of 5-star reviews, so if it looks interesting, give it a try.  You may like it better than I did (and I did buy the next book, so I think the series has some hope).
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on March 22, 2024

bookDescription: A Warhammer 40,000 NovelBelisarius Cawl is the greatest mind of his age, and he has a plan to open up the Attilan Gap to allow safe passage through the Great Rift. In order to complete his work, he travels to a necron tomb world. In the process, he attracts the attention of something even more dangerous than ancient xenos…READ IT BECAUSEBelisarius Cawl continues to be one of the most important figures in the 41st Millennium as he attempts to solve the greatest problem facing the Imperium – allowing safe passage through the Cicatrix Maledictum. He squares off against ancient necrons and the forces of Chaos in his audacious attempt to do the impossible.THE STORYFor years, Belisarius Cawl has nurtured an audacious plan to stabilise the Attilan Gap sufficiently that the Imperium might open a stable route into Imperium Nihilus. With the primarch Roboute Guilliman having crossed the Great Rift, and now isolated on the far side, time is running out.Before Cawl can perfect his latest great work, he requires one last element: control codes preserved on an ancient necron world trapped on the event horizon of a black hole. Realising that even he cannot do this alone, Cawl recruits help from across the Adeptus Mechanicus. Yet as victory nears, malign intelligences have taken note of the archmagos, and Cawl is about to discover it is unwise indeed to provoke the interest of Vashtorr the Arkifane…Written by Guy Haley.

bookDescription: Seek the GalaxyBook 3 in the Multi-Award-Winning Return to the Galaxy SeriesThey found the tech to reach the stars. But the galaxy they enter is burning.On Earth, the team suffers betrayal, torture, and death at the hands of brutal enemies.Ewan and his companions discover a hidden Saret asteroid base brimming with futuristic technology. When they uncover a fully operational interstellar warship, humanity’s dream of returning to the stars finally seems within reach.Armed with advanced ships and weapons, they set out to find lost human colonies, hoping for allies. Instead, they find bloody chaos.On Kifrun, a malevolent God-King rules through dark sacrifices and ancient terror, plotting to invade a peaceful republic. To stop him, Ewan’s team must fight on two worlds, and their best chance may lie with a desperate girl thief with fire in her heart and nothing left to lose.Admiral Velal leads her Space Marines in desperate clashes against hostile alien powers, fighting to protect a fleet of vulnerable refugees and keep her people alive.And in the outer reaches, Beryn, medieval prince turned starfighter ace, must choose which civilizations live or die, as the Ranid wipe out human worlds in waves of nuclear annihilation.If Earth is to survive, allies must be found, old wounds must heal, and humanity must face its darkest hour.Not all of them will make it. But if they fail, Earth burns next.Perfect for fans of John Scalzi, Orson Scott Card, and Jack Campbell, Seek the Galaxy delivers cinematic action, epic battles, and brutal moral choices in a galaxy where survival is never guaranteed.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Another Superlative Offering by BA Gillies
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Another superlative offering!Seek the Galaxy is the third book in Gillies’ Return to the Galaxy series. I give it ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️/5! I’ve read them all (twice so far), and they are all so good!  It has been many years since I’ve read a series in which the excitement of the story AND the superior quality of the writing is not just maintained but improves with each new title.In Seek the Galaxy, we are again kept informed of Velal’s trials and tribulations. She searches ahead of the Ranid’s course into the Orion arm, hoping to protect or perhaps transplant Saret colonists. Ewan and Jera struggle for control of the effort to prepare earth to defend against the expected Ranid attack.Gillies didn’t start writing fiction until just over two years ago. Yet his handling of this complex story is incredible; he manages the story from multiple perspectives and locations. What I find so unusual is that he doesn’t just take ideas from past great writers and mix them in a different order. Instead he has new ideas, new concepts, new ways of handling various pieces of the story. Are there some ideas I have seen before? Yes, it IS a space opera, after all— but he gives them his own spin.In Seek the Galaxy, we are again kept informed of Velal’s trials and tribulations. She searches ahead of the Ranid’s course into the Orion arm, hoping to protect or perhaps transplant Saret colonists. Ewan and Jera struggle for control of the effort to prepare earth to defend against the expected Ranid attack.I believe the digital version of these titles has been developed by an expert IT professional. They are well organized; I’ve had no problems identifying the source, location, and time of each section of the story. Each section is linked in the Contents, not just by chapter, making Gillies’ books exceptionally easy to navigate. All appear to be professionally edited as well. Frankly, I’ve seldom found this level of professionalism by independents in digital publishing at all, let alone by relatively new authors.Gillies is a wonderful writer. His initial works certainly compare favorably with the greats of science fiction—including Heinlein, Asimov, and McCaffrey. (And Gillies is still publishing!) If you love science fiction, you’ll love Seek the Galaxy. Book 4, Explore the Galaxy, is scheduled to be released October 6, 2025.

bookDescription: With the GCH on the ropes, Jackson risks everything to turn the tide of the war before it's too late. It all comes down to this in 'Legacy - The Shroud of Darkness'. The action-packed fifth installment of the Legacy series.The GCH is in full lockdown after the deadly attack on one of its core systems, its desperation mounting. While Command considers its next move, Captain William Jackson and Admiral Valentyen devise a risky plan to steal critical intel in order to take down the Imperium's crippling weapon, the Shroud of Darkness.Jackson must venture deep into enemy territory once more, putting his life on the line as he travels on an unarmed cargo ship on a perilous trade mission with the GCH's only allies inside the Imperium, the enigmatic Mantises. But first, they'll need to evade the deadly Scorpion raiders that plague the route to the Mantis system, hunting and mutilating the crews who dare to support their former slaves.If they succeed, the GCH Fleet will need to react quickly, mounting a massive offensive that could turn the tide of the war, or be their final battle. The fate of the Confederation rests on discovering the secrets of the Shroud of Darkness and taking it down once and for all.No matter the cost.This is the continuing story of William Jackson and the fifth book in the Legacy series.

bookDescription: The multi award winning series that hit #1 best seller in seven Amazon categoriesThe war for the galaxy turns brutal. The Ranid have found the Wild Colonies, and they intend to burn them clean. Cradle Colony is under assault. The Ranid unleash wave after wave of dreadnoughts, Marines and nuclear bombardment. Yet Suna Fidam refuses to yield, leading one of the most audacious last stands in Saret naval history.Beneath the devastation, four trapped lieutenants race to survive a collapsing world, hunted by Ranid killers and betrayed by one of their own. Their struggle becomes the spark of something larger, proof that even in annihilation, the brave fight back.Across the Orion Arm, Velal gathers a massive relief fleet while Vidas pushes into uncharted space to search for allies among lost Wild Colonies.On Earth, Ewan Scott faces his most dangerous enemy yet. Human intelligence agencies would rather kill him than believe the truth about the coming war.Brutal, desperate and epic in scale, Fight for the Galaxy is perfect for fans of Scott Bartlett, John Scalzi, Craig Alanson and Glynn Stewart.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: BA Gillies: my favorite living sci-fi writer!
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Fight for the Galaxy continues to showcase BA Gillies’ ability to present this very complex story in a coherent way, beginning with a battle between Saret and Ranid fleets. Battles continue throughout, literally and politically. Themes of loyalty vs betrayal and cowardice vs. bravery are skillfully woven throughout. There are successes but also heartbreaking losses.Earth’s secret agencies and top military commanders become more worried, fearful and aggressive towards SUS and its people. Some countries work together in their desires to control SUS, making serious attempts to steal its secret technology. Some  prove willing to torture and kill SUS scientists and leaders in their attempts to gain this information.The Orion Federation works to support the people and legitimate leaders on colonies originally planted by the Saret. Plans are made to move willing populations to new planets in order to hide them from the Ranid. Saret Admiral Velal and her fleet continue to look for Saret colonies and fight the Ranid in fierce battles. In both Federations, the themes of bravery vs cowardice and loyalty vs betrayal continue. We are left with a cliffhanger (which I still don’t like!), but once again, Gillies has left us a bit of the beginning of Book 6 Stand for the Galaxy, which helps a little.I’ve purchased, read and loved all five volumes in this series so far (Some more than once!) I was excited to receive an early free ARC for Book 5 Fight for the Galaxy, and this review reflects my honest opinion of it. I continue to love each book as the drama and excitement builds, anticipating the final volume, Book 6 Stand for the Galaxy.Gillies has hit all the usual features of a classic space opera, but added his own unique twist, updating the classic space opera. It has the usual complex storylines, many characters with varying beliefs, goals, emotions, moral codes, etc., in different cultures, multiple locations, with exceptionally long timelines.The format serves to keep the reader informed of the next point of view, speaker, location and often the timing and/or what is happening. I especially appreciate this feature, as it helps me easily keep track of who, what, where, when, and why. The editing and overall formatting is again superb; I noted no typos or misspelled words.  I am in awe at Gillies’ imagination, coupled with his ability to keep this very complicated series in his mind and give it to us in an understandable form.If you like classic space operas, you will love his updated version, including this volume, Fight for the Galaxy. I certainly do! and give it ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️. I recommend starting this series from the beginning, with Book 1 Return to the Galaxy.Booklover11-23-2025

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Awesomely awesome..Unless you don't like cliffhanger endings, which the author loves... but not the reader ^^I have been hooked on this series from the first book.If you like Starship Troopers, Undying Mercenaries, Expeditionary Forces, and empire building then this is for you. And when I mean empire building, it's nicely done. Just missing the Terran guys sending the terrorists/alphabet a 3-ton meteor to keep them quiet.I would note as well as the author does a VERY compelling job of mixing at least 3 different timelines with different POV. It's building a final confrontation that will be memorable. Usually authors crash down into some non-sensical time-travel and discontinuity traits, but for this series, I would say it's well built.Battles are very well choreographed,  the pacing is fast, and 5 seconds after opening the book, you will already be screaming, "Where's the rest? how will it end?"I would recommend the author to get some Kevlar-reinforced gloves to write way faster!
