bookDescription: What would you do if you were given a second chance?Titus Briggs is an Earth Defense soldier, a grunt, a decorated war hero—it's all he's ever known. So when a career-ending injury leaves him lying in a hospital bed, missing both legs, he struggles to accept his new reality. He can no longer walk, which means he can no longer fight.That is, until a mysterious colonel arrives and offers Titus the opportunity to step into a new kind of war, a new kind of fight.To become a new kind of soldier.Mobile Combat Suits—MOCOMS—represent the next stage in human warfare. They enable soldiers to fight like never before. Stronger. Faster. Bristling with weaponry. Far more lethal.And even a broken veteran like Titus can operate one… if he can find the heart, grit, and determination needed to pass selection.Now, with the end of humanity upon him, Titus must become the Able-Bodied Soldier.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Able Bodied Soldier - a fight for the planet
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I have found that any book with writers Chaney and Anspach is one to read. 'Able Bodied Soldier' is one of those. War, no matter where it's fought, leaves a permanent emotional and, in many cases, permanent physical scars.I have seen how technological advances have given a few the ability to return to a somewhat normal life. A wonderful organization called the 'Wounded Warrior Project'* is a non-profit tax deductible group that is instrumental in helping those men and women who gave all they could in the real world.In this book, 'Able Bodied Soldier', the reader can feel some of the emotional pain when the main character, Titus Briggs, experiences what he fears will be the end of his life as a soldier. Since he was pulled from high school, Briggs has been in the forefront fighting the invading aliens. He is now a military leader in the thick of battling hostiles for the security of the planet. Former Beatle John Lennon wrote in one of his famous songs, 'Beautiful Boy', - "Life is what happens while you're busy making other plans...". Today, for Titus Briggs, life happens.This is a great military style story that brings all of the tension you'd expect. Couple the excellent writing with the narration by one of the very best in the business, R.C. Bray, and for me, the perfect book. - Mr.Bill*woundedwarriorproject.org
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Excellent story, well-imagined and well told. Battle segments are especially well done, characters are nicely drawn. I will follow this series.My only quibbles are the periodic grammar mistakes that are like potholes and break your train of thought. Words like "none" and "every" (and a couple dozen others) are SINGULAR no matter how many plural clauses you hang on them. A sentence like "None of the soldiers were wearing their helmet" is flat wrong. None WAS wearing HIS helmet (unless they had one common helmet they took turns wearing). When the gender is unknown or mixed, classic grammar specifies the masculine. If that is too un-PC for you, you have to use the cumbersome "his or her" or reword the sentence to something like "None of the soldiers wore a helmet."Nevertheless, I'm eager for Book 2.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I had previously read something by Chaney, something scifi, so I keep seeing his books in my recommendations.What I had a problem with is that this book is a little scifi and a whole lot of war. Now, I am a senior citizen, so it takes something to make me squeamish. This book is violent, but not gory. But it is full of military jargon and abbreviations. But many were undefined. So many  it knocked down from 5 ⭐'s to 3. Now I tried using the Internet to search for these definitions, but often the results were either non military or not found. Take AA for example. In a general context it is usually an abbreviation for Alcoholics Anonymous. In the context here, I figured it was something to do with aviation and/or armaments. 🤔 The point being a reader shouldn't have to stop reading to try to figure these things out!I also have a general pet peeve regarding the books I read - or two. First, is typos. Because any published book should have a professional editor to find these errors (and we all make them). Second is grammar. Actually, this is my biggest pet peeve. I grew up reading books. Not just any books, but the classics. Several by Charles Dickens, others like Black Beauty, and so many more; too many to mention. Reading taught me more about grammar than I ever was taught in school. Correct grammar just "sounds" right to me because I was exposed to it in a fundamental way. It wasn't so much about learning rules, as learning it intuitively through reading. So when I read "I and my friends," for example, it's like fingernails on a chalkboard. I can occasionally overlook it if it's appropriate for the speaker, but it's still grating. I will say, that there are fewer grammatical errors with Chaney than some others I have read.In conclusion to my review and rant, if an author is writing about a specialized topic, it is absolutely necessary to define and explain to the reader who is not an expert in that arena. But this really is a good book, and I plan to read the sequel.

bookDescription:
Humanity balances on the cusp of extinction. The Coven Empire is preparing one final push to penetrate Fleet lines and invade the inner planets. What follows will be servitude, suffering, and death.
Cole Jackson and his small crew of misfits are trapped behind enemy lines, frantically trying to cobble together functioning starships while avoiding enemy patrols. It’s Fate that sees Jackson resurrect Freedom, the ship where he was first posted but now a derelict relegated to the military scrapyard. Using stolen alien technology, they seize a Coven prison colony and rescue captured Fleet personnel.
Jackson receives word that Fleet is ready to launch one final Hail Mary; a taskf orce equipped with a revolutionary new weapon. But first they must learn the location of the Coven Home World and only Jackson is in position to gather that intel.
Commanding a small fleet of salvaged vessels, Jackson ventures deep into Coven space. The human race is running out of time, and it’s up to him to find the Coven planet and rally the remnants of the task force in a last gasp attempt to defeat the aliens and save mankind.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Good, but uneven towards the end.
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Eisenhorn takes place in the Warhammer 40k universe and if you haven't read a book in this particular genre then you could do worse than start here.  Eisenhorn describes the life and times of Gregor Eisenhorn an Imperial Inquisitor.  The Inquisition is what you might expect given the naming; it's an organization that ruthlessly seeks out and destroys the 40k version of heretics and other things deemed improper by the Imperium of Man (the human side of things in this universe).  Those improper things encompass a wide range, but primarily the Inquisition seeks out and destroys those forces dedicated to spreading Chaos.  Chaos in the Warhammer 40k universe is a malevolent force that derives from the Warp and manifests itself physically in the form of daemons and those who utilize the Warp energies to further the agenda of Chaos.  That agenda is nothing less than the destruction of the universe and the order it represents.That's the basis for what Gregor Eisenhorn fights against and it's a constant struggle for members of the Inquisition against Chaos as Chaos is able to corrupt so easily and members of the Inquisition are so frequently exposed to sources of Chaos. The Eisenhorn stories are part action adventure and part mystery and Abnett does a good job of pacing things and keeping the reader on their toes.  The various stories in the book describe Eisenhorn's wide ranging adventures in his fight against Chaos and the temptations that he avoids and those that he falls prey to. Eisenhorn employs a large coterie of characters as part of his retinue so the book is not solely focused on him, though it tends to revolve around him.The weak point of the book takes place in the last third as there is a time shift that disconnects the first two books from the last and leaves the reader feeling somewhat adrift as many of the familiarities of the first two books are swept away.  The last book also loses some of the breakneck pacing of the first two and drags a bit.  Other than that the Omnibus itself is overall quite entertaining.  While Abnett has not really written any more Eisenhorn stories he continues in this vein in Ravenor.  The Ravenor character is derived from these Eisenhorn stories and while not required it's probably best to read this set of stories before reading Ravenor.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2011

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This book was my first foray into the Warhammer 40k Universe and I am now worried I have may have spoiled myself!This book was incredibly good.  Fascinating, fast paced, and with great characters development.  I have rarely read a book this fast.  Let alone 4 in 1.If I HAD to give a fair criticism, it would be that the endings of most of the books felt rather abrupt. Three of them could have used with more falling action, but at least the last book, The Magos, fortunately closed in a satisfying manner.HIGHLY recommended!
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on June 13, 2023

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This compilation was the 'last chance' read for dan abnett in my book, after what I considered contrived or overt insertion of coincidences to introduce plot items or devices/resolutions in First and Only and Fell Cargo.  I particularly felt first and only was entirely too contrived in the introduction of elements of gaunt's background, each as needed for the plot.  Maybe he was limited in space or had strict outlines there, but in any event....this series had none of those flaws.  First-person narrative read well, and usually quickly, with no sense of contrived coincidences just to move the plot along, and few if any of the cliche plot turns that I disliked in the books i mentioned above.  Furthermore, Abnett shows his tremendous ability to describe enviroments, worlds, cities, through language.  When he describes a Hive-city, a small village, a trans-alpine railway, you feel like you are seeing it.Another great strength of this story, particularly Hereticus, is the development of his ability to write very competent antagonists.  A major defect in much sci-fi, BL and not, is the use of cardboard-cutout antagonists, who leave you wondering how they ever rose to their position in the first place.  The major antagonist in this trilogy, Pontius Glaw, shows early signs of the extreme competence without omnipotence that some villains from his later Ravenor series show.Edit - 4th re-read, 08.2008 - Having read everything else by Abnett, and gained a lot of familiarity with W40k in general, I would like to offer that this is a great trilogy.One thing that caught my eye this time was an aspect of Ravenor that was apparently dropped in the Ravenor novels - His Lord Seer eldar that he referred to in the last part of this trilogy.  The implication was that Ravenor was subservient or at the very least allied with the Eldar, something Abnett seems to have just dropped in the follow-up series.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2006

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: One of the best reads I've had in years
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: I loved reading every second of this. I'm just a mom who would normally turn my nose at something Warhammer, but was convinced to try and enjoy the complex and rich lore by a family member. I couldn't put the Eisenhorn omnibus down, cover to cover I read the entire thing in less than a week, and then read it again. This and Space Wolves were fantastic gateways into the Warhammer universe. I've since bought several more Warhammer book series and am devouring them. This particular work was excellent and Abnett is a great writer, he avoided the sloppy, lazy, low vocabulary writing I've seen littering most modern "literature". The pace is excellent, the surprises and character developments were great, the story arcs were well done. I really really loved this series and look forward to the Ravenor books.

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: An incredible journey through the Warhammer universe
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: Eisenhorn: The Omnibus is an outstanding read for anyone who enjoys Warhammer 40,000 lore or gripping science fiction in general. The stories are rich and immersive, with Gregor Eisenhorn as a central character who feels complex, intelligent, and morally compelling. The blend of detective-style mystery with the dark, expansive Warhammer setting keeps you hooked from start to finish.I was particularly impressed by the depth of the world-building. The various factions, technologies, and political intrigues feel detailed and believable, and the author does a great job of balancing action with character development. Each book in the omnibus flows seamlessly into the next, making it easy to binge-read while still appreciating the nuances of the story.Overall, this is one of the best Warhammer novels I have read. The writing is engaging, the plot is well-paced, and it brings the universe to life in a way that both long-time fans and newcomers can enjoy. I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a captivating and intelligent sci-fi experience.
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on September 30, 2025

bookDescription:
A retired captain. An experimental starship. A war like no other.
When the research starship Galileo vanishes without a trace, the powers-that-be are quick to bury the incident, eager to prevent escalating tensions that could lead to war. As a former POW, Soren refuses to give the ship up for lost.
His daughter is one of the missing.
Taking matters into his own hands, Soren starts pulling strings and calling in favors, determined to launch a clandestine mission to bring Galileo home. When an old friend offers him a ship for the operation, he expects a rusty relic headed for the scrapyard.
Instead, he's given the Wraith—an unfinished, experimental starship with plenty of potential and just as many problems. A marvel of engineering…if his crew can keep her running.
They’d better.
Because Galileo’s disappearance is just the beginning. War is coming to the Federation from the most unlikely of places.
And Soren may be the only one who can stop it.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I was a bit hesitant to start into this book, having read many reviewers stating how much different this book is from Ender's Game.  It's true, Speaker is its own beast; a distinctly different tone, setting, pace and plot, but it has the same basic premise and spirit. The significant difference, in my mind, is the level of maturity. Whereas Ender's Game was fast paced, and written in a manner that anyone of practically any age can enjoy, Speaker is geared more towards a mature reader, and is written with greater emotional and philosophical depth.On its own, Speaker could have been a great novel, but I think Card's decision to write Ender as a full novel gives Speaker even more depth and meaning. If the only thing you really enjoyed from Ender was the battles, then there's not much need to read this book - give yourself a few years, reread Ender, and give yourself a chance to appreciate the human interactions of Ender, because to me that was the greatest strength of Ender as well as Speaker. Once you fully appreciate Ender, there's no way you won't appreciate and love this novel as well.Speaker is a great story, with fantastic characters that jumped off the page for me, and it was highly satisfying to see Ender as a man. However, I did feel that the novel gave short shrift to its early characters and that some of the philosophy that is delved into in the next book, Xenocide, could have been brought forward and fleshed out here. I think that perhaps an additional 50-100 pages would have been sufficient to bring more life and meaning to the characters before Ender arrives.Despite this, Speaker is one of the best novels that I've ever read. It is masterfully written, and conceived. I'm sure that even though this book does give a feeling of completion in term of plot resolution at the end, you will want more, and the next two novels in the series will be a necessary read for everyone.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2013

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: The story of the never ending search for alien life and one way we could survive.
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This review is for the Kindle edition ebook.This is the follow up to "Ender's Game". It is the story of how Ender Wiggin learned to cooperate with alien life, rather than destroy it. In the first book, Ender learns to play a computer game that eventually wipes out an entire alien race. In this book, Ender must deal with the guilt and pain of causing that race to disappear. He also has learned not to make that mistake again.I really got into this story. I do believe we will encounter alien life before the world ends. How we deal with that encounter is always a question. This book is a fictional account of one way to deal with that alien life encounter. I felt the Introduction was too long for this book. I am not one who wants all the background behind the story at the front of the book. I would rather the author explain this at at the end. I want to read the story, then will read the explanations.I find the idea of someone speaking about the dead in a manner that correctly emphasizes their life and goals as very inspiring. I have been to more funerals than I care to count, and most of the time, the dead are spoken of as almost perfect. They were not that way in life, and yet, we, the survivors, find it very difficult to express their lives in real terms. I do not intend any disrespect to the dead, but it would certainly be refreshing to have a speaker that could put their life into perspective sometimes.I would like to say "Thank you, Orson Scott Card", for actually being able to express these thoughts I have had for so many years. Your book should be an inspiration to the living world wide. We should never jump to conclusions about the unknown, nor should we revere the dead above their actual life.I find this book much more reality based than the first book, "Ender's Game". For me, it is much better, and I will definitely be reading more of this author's books. While Game is fast-paced and exciting, this book is more involved. It is not a computer simulator game story, instead, it is the story of someone's life and their struggles. While it is fiction, it is an excellent view into the future of mankind. I highly recommend this book to those readers of science fiction who allow themselves to believe in the possibility of alien life.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2013

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: I want to be a Speaker when I grow up
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This book got me from the instant I saw the title.  I felt compelled to read it, at least sample it.  I have not read Ender’s Game nor seen the movie.  Even though this is part of the Ender Quintet, Speaker stands on its own.  Storywise, it does come after Ender’s Game because Ender is all grown up now, but I did not feel I was missing any background and was able to piece together the history as I read the book .Speaker for the Dead is an amazing book; I could not put it down.  The author is philosophical, but in a way that makes you understand more about yourself and things around you.  I cried tears of grief and tears of great amazement in reading this book.Truth, lies, good and evil, life, death and rebirth; all defined from a slightly different point of view.The author’s introduction, explaining a bit about his thought process and how he wrote the book led me to believe there was going to be something very gory and evil in the way life is sustained on Lusitania.  Nothing could be further from the truth.  The whole life cycle of the piggies turned out to be VERY different from anything we know on Earth, but so awesomely beautiful, I felt as if I could easily live in harmony with them on Lusitania.Anthropological research protocols definitely come into question in this book.  The author challenges you – what would you do in this situation?  Would you insist that these beautiful but very different beings be brought to human standards?  Would that be right?  What if YOU were that Xenador (researcher) would you do the same and try to benefit the beings you were studying or would you try cold-heartedly to stick to protocol?  I cannot even explain the depth of this author’s understanding of the human mind, fixed ideas, religion, politics, the rise and fall of civilizations; and space travel of course.If Enders Game made a good movie, Speaker for the Dead would be totally epic.This book has a fairy tale ending.  In the end, I have only one question – can we trust the hive queen?

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: Una storia allo stesso tempo ricca di elementi classici della fantascienza rimescolati però in una storia non complicata ma originale e che tocca vari temi non banali. Ho apprezzato particolarmente l'ideazione e la presentazione degli alieni: apparentemente "molto terrestri" ma in molte cose davvero stranianti.

One of the best SF books I have read. Beats its prequel hands down!While Ender's Game was pretty good, this book is far more diverse, and explores a whole lot of new ideas. Card just enthralls us with this universe of his. The way he slowly builds up the piggies' world and pulls you in.. just brilliant.Characterization is top-notch. Ender is shown to be a much more complex guy, than the child prodigy as shown in #1. And the new characters are pretty awesome as well.. Jane, Miro, Human, Libo.. Everyone has a pretty vital part in the storyline.<Spoiler>The signing of the covenant between the humans and the piggies was the best part of the book. Really mind-blowing stuff, with powerful dialogues.</Spoiler>A definite must-read for SF lovers.

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: Amazing book with emphasis on thought more than action
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: I really enjoyed Ender's Game, but Speaker for the Dead was even better.While Ender's Game was written as background for Speaker for the Dead, I think that the books should be read in the order they were published which also makes it chronologically correct: First Ender's Game, then Speaker for the Dead (Ender in Exile is chronologically in between, but I haven't read it yet and it was published years later) In Ender's Game the story evolves around very intelligent children, which makes it interesting for both young and old. Speaker for the Dead seems more mature to me. (Be aware) I'm not sure if the book would be comprehendable and interesting enough for younger kids.The books combine an interesting sci-fi story with intelligence and unusual characters. Personally I enjoy following Ender's thoughts the most. Card describes the characters' reasoning in great detail, which is the interesting part to me while not describing every detail of every landscape or room as so many other fantasy authors do. I really appreciate that since it keeps the story going forward all the time.Even though I have to agree it is not an adventure story in the normal sense, I think in the way it discusses humanity, the impact of truth it never feels boring or too long. There is not a lot of fighting going on, rather an understanding and questions about the way humans treat other species. All in all it is a very intellectual book about how we should also treat each other in understanding our differences.I'm currently reading the third book "Xenocide", and would already recommend reading the whole series.

Jacob Grimm returns as CO of USS Interceptor just a few weeks after he graduated from command school. He’s immediately sent on a rescue mission to the far side of Zuckabar, with no backup and dwindling supplies.When an unknown enemy cripples his ship on the outskirts of the system, the crew must come together and track their mysterious foe out into the unknown.An incredible discovery leads them to another system. Trapped on the wrong side of a starlane with an enemy that outguns them and civilians to rescue, Jacob must push his crew to the very edge of their ability.If he can’t, they will all die out in the black with no way to warn the Alliance of the new threat on their doorstep, and all two million souls on Kremlin Station will pay for his failure.From USA Today bestselling author Jeffery H. Haskell comes book two in the military science fiction epic in the tradition of Honor Harrington and Star Trek. If you love heroes and ships you will want to stand With Grimm Resolve against Interceptor’s latest enemy. You’re in the Navy now!

aPlusContent.title: From the Publisher
aPlusContent.rawText:
From the Publisher
The wrong crew. The wrong ship. The right Captain. 
Disgraced and denied promotion, Jacob’s career is over. That is until the head of ONI needs a disposable officer to command a battered destroyer on the rim. 
There’s just one problem, Interceptor hasn’t had a CO in months and the ship is a mess. Worse, the system he’s assigned to is corrupt and on the verge of all-out civil war with the Alliance. 
However, no one told Jacob he was disposable. 
Pirates, smugglers, and Caliphate spies complicate the situation and one captain with an old ship can’t enforce the law, let alone stop anyone. 
The single greatest discovery of all time is about to change intergalactic politics forever. If Jacob doesn’t find a way to succeed, then it won’t just be the end of the Alliance, it will be the end of freedom for humanity. 
"Classic space fleet military science fiction in the tradition of David Weber." — Rick Partlow, author of Contact Front 
A New Classic in Mil SF! 
"Compulsively readable and delightfully original. It's classic science fiction for today's reader: a brutal, smart, fast-paced adventure."—Rachel Aukes, author of Space Troopers 
Detailed Military Action. 
"Jeffery H. Haskell introduces a detailed world that feels so real from page one all the way to its epic ending."—Jonathan Yanez, author Forsaken Mercenary 
Gritty and Heartfelt! 
"Against All Odds is both gritty and heartfelt, both action-packed and character-driven. Fans of military science fiction will love it."—Daniel Arenson, USA Today author of Starship Freedom 
Heroes and Starships. 
"Best author with his fly down,"—Larry Correia, author of Monster Hunter International.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: #2 in the Grimm's War series.We follow along with the destroyer Interceptor and her crew as they head out to rescue some hostages held by the smarmy Guild. The Guild controls most of the tech and all of the terraformers being used by both the Alliance and their enemies, the Caliphate. (The Guild is kind of like a combination Microsoft/Apple/mafia in this universe.) Whenever there are shady doings, the Guild is behind it. The only reason they're tolerated is because they have the monopoly on terraformers. So anyway, Jacob and his crew set out to find the hostages. They find more than they bargained for, too.The characters are just as enjoyable as the first book. They each have distinct personalities, mannerisms and quirks. Jacob isn't a Special Snowflake, either. He makes mistakes and follows suggestions from his crew. I really like the cast! The pacing was decent, too. Things moved along fairly quickly and I was never bored.I could sit here and nitpick my issues with the series but none of them are really earth shattering. The use of modern slang and the stereotypical religion/society of the main enemy were the two main detractors. Despite these flaws, I plan to read the next one in the series.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I do like to read stories of action and adventure in space.What makes this even more enjoyable is the fact that not everything is perfect. Supplies can run low. There is not an infinite amount of ammunition or power to fight prolonged engagements.Tactics and discipline. Not just shoot from the hip and pray.I also like the use of the towed array. Just like earth submarines. Makes sense and is believable here.Intelligence gathering, study of history, and making use of other peoples’ skills make this a great story.Now to see what they are up to next!!

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Grimm is the commander we need
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: A great follow up to Against All Odds! This may be better than the first book. There are no boring, middle-of-a-trilogy bridge moments here.Haskell writes about great space battles and cool tech but his strong point is definitely his character building. I believe these crew members exist. As a matter of fact, I’m pretty sure I served with someone exactly like most of them.The crew is loyal to Grimm and for good reason.This book has a positive theme and is a feel-good book. We know Grimm’s going to win. The fun part is watching it as it happens.I’m excited to read  the last one.Highest recommendation. Phenomenal book!

Die Figuren und der Plot lehnen sich deutlich an die Honor Harrington Serie von D. Weber an, was kein Fehler sein muss. Dieser Autor legt seinen Schwerpunkt stärker auf die Aktionelemente und im ersten Band ist ihm dabei eine gute Balance gelungen, in diesem übertreibt er dabei für meinen Geschmack und noch mehr stören mich eine Reihe kaum nachvollziehbarer Handlungen der Protagonisten, sowie etliche physikalische Ungereimtheiten.Auch wenn Weber manchmal etwas zu detailverliebt in seinen Beschreibungen der Raumschiffe, der politischen Fraktionen und seiner Gefechte ist, so sind seine Figuren mit viel Liebe und Sachverstand entwickelt und der Plot ist stimmig.Ber dieser Reihe vermisse ich zu viel davon.

bookDescription: After two decades of learning at the Nexus, the children of Van and his crew are ready to take their first steps out in the big black.Aboard their new ship, the AnaDarko, the young officers begin unraveling a mystery that goes beyond the depths of time—where did Gabby’s people come from, and why does life, scattered across the gas giants, all sound so familiar to her?Under the capable guidance of Rab, a seasoned Peacemaker, the young crew pursues science and knowledge—even as Van and Torina push back against a threat that originates on earth itself.Politics is a dirty business, and with Constance Plowitz’ retirement, the scramble for control of earth’s future falls in the hands of someone who sees the Fist of Orion not as a partner——but an enemy.But Van is two decades older, and wiser, and the crew, along with Perry and Funboy and Icky—are that much better at their specialty—dispensing justice.There are old friends, new faces, and a power struggle whose roots go back to when known space was young, empires were old, and war was the answer.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Twenty years later and old problems may be returning....
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This novel catches us up 20 years after the events of the last book meaning that the kids are now becoming or are adults. This therefore is a connecting bridge between the old generation and the new, though the old does not a backseat.Connections between certain lifeforms living in gaseous and liquid conditions and Gabi are discovered, though someone doesn't want these uncovered.... There appears to be a new (or is it an old) foe who maybe trying to thwart the success of the Nexus and exploit humanity as certain events occur and clues are uncovered.This novel dwells deeply on Parenthood and your fears for your children as well as introducing the new generation as they learn the ropes. There is suspense, surprise, intrigue and the return of almost all the old favourites in this novel that relaunches/continues the Backyard Starship saga. A fun read for all fans and new converts to the series.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Love this series. I actually thought it was over once the kiddos graduated in that final scene if book (?) 25.  I thought then that the kids were going to be a spinoff from there. Imagine my surprise when I found that wasn’t the case and I’d already missed a couple of new releases. That doesn’t usually happen. I usually place release dates in calendar so I can get it immediately. That’s how much I love this group of characters, their history, present and where they’re headed. I esp love the amount of action and drama within each book. You literally never know what kind of trouble they’ll find next. I didn’t find this one near as dramatic as the last time they had a huge run in with a politician who ultimately betrays themselves as a character ready to take down the crew or Earth, itself. One of the big differences was the extreme limited character interaction this time around compared to that past character, who was a similar, enemy character.The finale was good, if a bit rushed & I’m looking forward to next book.‼️Spoiler alert******‼️I still do not understand the reason behind the appearance of the fake US ship at the moon where the Darko crew were doing research on new alien beings. It served no purpose other than to clue the crew and subsequently Van that all was not well on Earth and their first target was the politician. But again, for what purpose? Why draw attention to yourself when you’ve laid low from the law, at least, if not the public , this whole time? All it did was place a giant target on his back. So why do that? And he didn’t show interest after that, even though the Drako continued its research flights. That part just doesn’t make sense to me. Maybe the next book will bring it all together. 🤷🏻‍♀️🤞🤞. PS—I’m hoping they find a way (or Myriam decides to take the anti-aging meds) to turn time back or, at least to slow it down now that she has finally found her own happy story. After all, she’s given her life to help raise and protect Van; it would seem a small way to thank her and keep her as part of the story, especially when she could be more a part of something substantial with her new male friend.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2025

I recommend this series to anyone!

title: Glory: Humanity's Last Hope
author: Ira Heinichen
breadCrumbs: Kindle Store > Kindle eBooks > Science Fiction & Fantasy > Science Fiction > Military > Space Fleet

attributes.value: #16,299 in Kindle Store (See Top 100 in Kindle Store) #84 in Space Exploration Science Fiction eBooks#90 in Space Marine Science Fiction eBooks#135 in Space Fleet Science Fiction eBooks

bookDescription: One last chance for Glory. One last hope for humanity.A ship pulled out of mothballs by the original crew, sent to fight a war humanity was losing.Glory barely survived its last battle twenty years earlier. Captain Drake resigned rather than face court martial. But the enemy is back. Humanity needs everything that can fly.Maybe it’s not the ship at all, but the crew. They hold the key.Drake rallies old and young alike to comply with orders so secret, even he wasn’t allowed to see them until after the ship left the junkyard. Would it leave? That was another question. The core hadn’t been fired in twenty years.The smell of decay filled the massive ship’s corridors. The stench of death lingered, the death of Drake’s crew, a nightmare from long ago.The Paragon have weapons that humanity couldn’t contemplate. But here they were, suing for peace. The people of Earth jumped at the carrot. The end of war! Could it be too good to be true?Drake had his orders from an admiral who knew too much. Glory must launch.And with it, the fate of humanity rested on the shoulders of a broken crew, carrying a weapon like no other, hoping for one clear shot.One last chance for Glory.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: I could not put this down. Best read in a LONG time!
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Holy crap, this was a great read! I went through this book in like 5 days because I could not put it down. I was going to bed early and planning time when I could read it it was so good. A book has not picked me up and taken me along with it using unstoppable force as a 100-foot wave in a long time. This was just excellent!I've known Ira Heinichen is a great writer since I read his debut novel Star Stuff, and Ira is lucky I'm a watchmaker with a lot of patience waiting for the Escape from Red Tower book 2. He was so good it is worth the wait. When I saw him team up with Craig Martelle, one of the undisputed masters of military sci-fi, it was a no-brainer. That was an insta-click for me. You put two phenomenal writers like that together and magic happens. And it did.The story and storyline were outstanding. The characters were true to life, flawed, and real, and relatable. The book reads like a movie, and it WOULD make a great movie.I do not want to go into any plot and it would be unfair to reveal spoilers. Suffice it to say that an unstoppable alien force, the Paragon, with more dirty tricks than seems possible, better technology, and unstoppable resources wants to swat the human race like a fly and exterminate us. Our saviors: 1 retired old starship captain, one untried crew, one untested fighter commander, and one great XO. once mighty ship in her Glory (sic) days, now mothballed, decrepit, and about done. And that's what we're counting on to save us. There are battles galore, between people, aliens, fighters, and capital ships. There are surprise saves, and there are some really, really big "didn't see that coming" surprises. Not to mention a cyborg marine, and - wait for it - a cyborg dog!I went through this book like Grant went through Richmond. And folks, I was preparing for a final defense on an advanced degree when I started this and finished it 5 days later. Not good planning to be sleep-deprived because I can't put the book down! (I still got an A).Suffice it to say, that this book would get 6 or 7 stars if I could give them. Will I read the 2nd book in the series, not yet published? Already pre-ordered! Would I recommend this? Hail, yes! Look, you can't go to theme parks and ride terrifying roller coasters at the moment due to the 'rona, so you might as well save the money and the hassle and just read this book.Craig, Ira, I know the Paragon aren't done yet, and there is a lot more story to tell. Keep writing
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2022

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: This is a great start to an excellent series!
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I just finished Glory: Humanity's Last Hope and I am eager to continue the series. The story is riveting and the cast of characters is unsurpassed. Ira Heinichen and Craig Martell create an epic story. The action is unrelenting and it contrasts the best of humanity versus an implacable enemy in the Paragon. The battles are plotted well and just when you think the stakes can't be higher - they get exponentially higher. Craig Martell's real world experience and Ira Heinichen's screen writer's eye for action and character development keep the reader immersed in the story.  This book would make an incredible movie yet I think no screen adventure would equal the pictures in my mind from the authors' prose. The ending is stirring, I got a little choked up and was sorry for the story to end -EXCEPT: the story ends with a foreshadowing to the next book Away we go!! Thanks for a absorbing read that took me away!

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: great story, to me, just hard to follow and visualize character positions sometimes.
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: *NON SPOILER REVIEW*Out of the 4 books that I have read of Denning, he always has good stories. The books as a whole almost always turn out to be a very good read. My only issue with Troy Denning's writing style (and this may just be me) is that I time and time again have issues in my minds eye visualizing the characters. Namely the directions that the characters are facing or where things are positioned. This may be a small complaint, especially since I say that his books are overall always good, but it does prove to disrupt the flow of the reading for me.With that being said, this book in particular was phenomenal in all of the right ways. To me, for those who watch anime, I would compare it similarly to how I have heard many compare One Piece to Naruto. Whereas Naruto focuses on individual plotlines and character development, One Piece lends more to world building. The Shadows of Reach spends a considerable time building the world in between and during  the missions, dialogue, and battle sequences. I thoroughly enjoyed it. The fall of Reach (Naruto) builds who the Spartans are. The Shadows of Reach (One Piece) returns to reach and builds up the world so to speak. obviously, you can say much more about the two but you get my drift.If I could add one more thing, read: Silent Storm, oblivion, Outcasts (standalone but to me is a sequel and necessary to fully appreciate Oblivion), then The shadows of Reach.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2024

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Blue Team in a modern setting
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Troy Denning has two of the three current threads of the Halo novels extended-universe. The first two "A Master Chief" stories occurred in a time in the Official Halo Timeline where John, Kelly, Fred, and Linda were teenagers, after Reach but before Halo: CE. Those felt like a retcon, but they didn't retcon anything, just added a story into the lore where there was a gap and/or no story (they put something in that really didn't need to be there since it was a past story and we already know how things played out, so it was self-contained and felt like a waste of time).This story, however, is after Last Light (so Fred has joined back up with his Blue Team group) and also after Halo 5: Guardians, and before Halo: Infinite. Unfortunately, H:I retcons this book in-that the game is the first time of Chief meeting Atriox and Escharum... in this book, however, the ending has Blue Team encountering Atriox and Escharum, including Master Chief, so it sorta felt like a letdown in the game that they ignored this book (like how Bungie ignored all the books in the original Halo trilogy).This book is great! Lots of exposition, and just the right amount of dialogue between Blue Team.

"Halo: Shadows of Reach" è un libro di fantascienza scritto da Troy Denning, che fa parte della serie di libri "Halo" basata sulla popolare serie di videogiochi. Questo libro segue la storia di Master Chief, il personaggio principale dei giochi "Halo", mentre si avventura in una missione per recuperare un oggetto misterioso dal pianeta Reach, che è stato devastato dalla guerra.Una delle cose più impressionanti del libro è la sua capacità di catturare l'atmosfera e la sensazione di avventura dei giochi "Halo". I lettori che amano i giochi saranno entusiasti di ritrovare il personaggio di Master Chief e l'universo "Halo" in una nuova avventura. Tuttavia, il libro non richiede necessariamente la conoscenza dei giochi per poterlo apprezzare. I lettori che amano la fantascienza e le storie di avventura apprezzeranno anche questo libro.La trama è ben sviluppata e piena di colpi di scena e momenti d'azione adrenalinici, che tengono il lettore impegnato e interessato fino alla fine. I personaggi sono ben sviluppati e interessanti, e la loro interazione e le loro relazioni sono ben gestite e sviluppate. Inoltre, la prosa di Denning è fluida e scorrevole, rendendo la lettura del libro un'esperienza piacevole.In definitiva, "Halo: Shadows of Reach" è un libro di fantascienza ben scritto e appassionante che soddisferà i fan della serie di giochi "Halo" e i lettori di fantascienza in generale. Se sei un fan dei giochi "Halo", o se ti piacciono le storie di avventura e di fantascienza, questo libro è altamente consigliato.
A great Halo book to read before Halo infinite eventually releases, highly recommended, it's a good read.

bookDescription: Explore the GalaxyThe sky is on fire. Nuclear firestorms rip through towns and villages. Ranid Marines descend through the ash, armored mandibles slick with human flesh.Admiral Velal Farn commands the last great Saret fleet. Every hesitation costs thousands of lives. Every mistake could doom millions when another Wild Colony burns. Attack too soon, and she may lose everything.On the Orion frontier, Ewan Scott uncovers the truth. The lost colonies aren’t havens. They’re slave pits, hunting grounds, killing fields. To save them, he must fight enemies with spears and chariots… and enemies with dreadnoughts.The Orion Federation is rising. The Ranid are hunting. Humanity stands in their path, untested, outnumbered, but unwilling to kneel.If you love Jasper T. Scott’s alien wars, Craig Martelle’s space fleets, or Scott Bartlett’s high-stakes battles, Explore the Galaxy will be your next obsession. Packed with ruthless enemies, desperate survival, and characters you’ll never forget.One-click now and join the fight.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Book 1 starts out slow and quickly gains speed

As an indication of how much I enjoyed these book, I finished them in slightly less than 3 weeks: sometimes reading to 3 AM.  I anxiously await the release of book 5 (around the end of November).  If you enjoy character development sprinkled with a little intense action, these books are a great read. The action is mainly on earth and a small part of our solar system and deep space over 1000's of light years slowly heading for a merging down the line.I found the writing slowly maturing as the books progressed.  I just recently discovered the these are the author's first books!  Books 5,6 and 7 are planned.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Explore the Galaxy by BA Gillies
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I continue to marvel at Gillies’ ability to take a common trope in science fiction—the space opera—and fill it full of  intriguing, fresh concepts and new ideas.Admiral Velal and her people face battles in Explore the Galaxy that demonstrate the greatest of heroism, superb strategy and especially, tactics. I am reminded of the battles in David Weber’s Honorverse. While the tactics are similar, as is the bravery and unflinching sacrifice, Gillies’ battles are condensed and more easily understood (at least by me). Otherwise, while Weber’s Honorverse is also a space opera, it is very different from Gillies’ Galaxy series. However, much as I love the Honorverse, overall I think Gillies’ writing quality is equal to Weber’s, just not its quantity!On earth, Ewan and company continue plans to bring the Saret’s scientific advances into common use globally so that humans will be able to defend earth if/when the Ranid attack. They face increasing problems from countries who want control of these advances for their own use, control and profit.Ewan and several others leave earth hoping to find other Saret colonies to aid in defending against the Ranid. They have many adventures before returning to serious trouble on earth. In addition, intelligence agents from several nations have begun to suspect and fear alien involvement in earth’s affairs, and are determined to interrogate SUS’ top recruits/Ewan, basically whoever else they can kidnap.While this series is very complex, with its large number of characters, multiple timelines, many locations, and multiple storylines, I always knew when in relation to the rest of the story and where a storyline was happening, what was happening in each section, why and to whom it was happening. I marvel at Gillies’ ability to conceive of this huge story, and then to organize it all to accomplish this successfully. It is nothing short of amazing.I continue to believe BA Gillies’ Galaxy series is superior to any other new science fiction I’ve read in years. Its latest entry, Book 4: Explore the Galaxy, is even better than the previous novel, Seek the Galaxy. It has space battles, Saret-planted colonies, planets suitable for new colonies, conflicts, betrayals, and more.I strongly recommend this series to everyone who likes speculative fiction. I suggest beginning with Book 1, Return to the Galaxy. I give Explore the Galaxy  ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ out of five stars.BookloverOctober 9, 2025

bookDescription:
The invasion was just the beginning.
The skies of New Rostov are burning. Its cities lie in ruins. Civilians are scattered, and the CDF is in shambles. Lieutenant Colonel Arthur Hanson must rise as the last officer capable of organizing resistance. The enemy is relentless, the odds are impossible, and the cost of every decision grows heavier by the hour.
Cut off from the CSV Margaret Thatcher, with limited personnel and few supplies, Arthur struggles to stay upright under the pressure of command. Yet, through every loss and every sacrifice, he keeps fighting.
As covert ops attempt to bring distant SATO allies into the fight, Arthur must hold the line against overwhelming odds—and strike from the shadows to hit the enemy where it hurts them the most.
Because heroes aren’t fearless. They’re the ones who fight anyway.

bookDescription:
Peace was only an illusion.
Terrorist attacks have decimated the CDF fleet in the Orion Spur, and reinforcements are hung up by the new administration’s pacifist politics. Lieutenant Colonel Arthur Hanson and the CSV Margaret Thatcher are left in a nightmare scenario:
They are on their own.
Amid the power plays, word reaches him of a mass hostage situation. Arthur resorts to any means necessary to discover their location—even under threat of mutiny and court martial. But with few Coalition ships left in the Spur, any rescue mission is doomed to fail.
But he won’t leave innocents to a fate worse than death.
Unwilling to turn aside, Arthur and the Special Forces under his command execute a hastily planned op worthy of their namesake ship. But the clock is ticking. They’ll have to pull out all the stops to free the hostages and halt Armageddon.
Before their time runs out.

aPlusContent.title: From the Publisher
aPlusContent.rawText:
From the Publisher
Peace was only an illusion. 
Insurgent attacks have decimated the CDF fleet in the Orion Spur, and reinforcements are hung up by the new administration’s pacifist politics. Lieutenant Colonel Arthur Hanson and the CSV Margaret Thatcher are left in a nightmare scenario: 
They are on their own. 
Amid the power plays, word reaches him of a mass hostage situation. Arthur resorts to any means necessary to discover their location—even under threat of mutiny and court martial. But with few Coalition ships left in the Spur, any rescue mission is doomed to fail. 
But he won’t leave innocents to a fate worse than death. 
Unwilling to turn aside, Arthur and the Special Forces under his command execute a hastily planned op worthy of their namesake ship. But the clock is ticking. They’ll have to pull out all the stops to free the hostages and halt Armageddon. 
Before their time runs out. 
Three more action-packed series are set in the Terran Diaspora Universe: 
Battlegroup Z 
After thirty-five years of peace, one vicious attack destroys it all. An unexpected enemy emerges with an overwhelming force designed to obliterate the Terran Coalition. Reservist Lieutenant Justin Spencer straps into the cockpit, determined to save his home from a vicious foe. 
Even outnumbered and outgunned, Justin is never out of the fight. 
Echoes of War Series 
Colonel David Cohen has sacrificed his dream of becoming a rabbi to help defend his home planet against the oppressive League of Sol. And even as he grapples with the lives lost under his command, David knows failure to defeat this merciless enemy is not an option. If he fails in his mission, billions face enslavement by a ruthless regime. Now it’s an all-out fight for the galaxy’s freedom. 
Because a man's greatest foe lies within. 
The Lost Warship Series 
The war with the League of Sol ended in victory for the Terran Coalition. Major General David Cohen and his crew conclude their three-month goodwill cruise with one final FTL jump. But instead of returning home in a blaze of glory, the wormhole collapses and hurls them more than four million lightyears into the unknown. 
Stranding them in a distant galaxy.

bookDescription:
Kill a man and you're a murderer. Kill a million and you're a statesman. Dirk should have killed more people.Dirriken Friedel used his aristocratic connections to rescue his troops. He didn’t plan on starting a war or killing them himself. Now he spends his days in jail, waiting for an assassin sent by his dead officers families to end his misery.
When he’s broken out by off-duty marines he has a chance to start over, if he’s worthy. During his ramshackle escape he collects a broken-down trading ship, a bitter former army officer, a genetically altered religious fanatic, a runaway ingenue, a sham engineer, and a murderous femme fatal. Pursed by a fanatical imperial tribune bent on bloody justice, can he keep the crew from killing each other, the ship from exploding, and himself from the bottom of a bottle. Or would it be easier just to give up?If you like Galactic Empires, honorable enemies, and snappy dialog, this one’s for you.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This was fun,  and had a great opening scene where one of our dubious heroes is telling his would be assassin how to do it better.  I liked that everyone had a backstory,  none of them were pure,  and the weird random luck that got them all on the ship.  It was a little too rollicking sometimes, not enough gravitas,  so it lost some points there.  But I'll read the next one.It's  a light, fast,  not too serious,  but still engaging read.  So works if that's the level you want.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Humanity itself at risk from alien invasion, the opportunity for galactic saviors to arise.Massive wars, naive friends, consistently prominent, pathetic good guys with plucky, plot-contorted success. Main characters who assemble an assorted cast of good people so they can “struggle” against slavers and genocides and hurt feelings before eventually cleaning them all out so they can be paladins for justice, complete with justifiably urine-scented capes while anything of value is “redeemed” in a new world order. Almost every space book on here is unpalatable and downright embarrassing for everyone involved. This author usually offers a decent contrast from the norm.I like the smaller scale and rough characters. They aren’t good people. They don’t have noble, “heroic” inner shells. They’re just people with their own motivations. Calling them criminals, let alone villains, is a stretch but they aren’t representing any childish wish fulfillment. That takes life experience and I think it’s actually pretty consistent for this author’s work. There are quite a few insightful human observations tucked away even if the dialog frequently veers from witty to indulgent. I think it’s obvious the purpose of this is to be fun and not to delve anywhere deep so it’s nothing to be uncharitable with.There are hints this new series will risk melting into a story about heroes, however, so the risk isn’t entirely done away with. If that happens without changing the description of this first title to warn anyone I’ll change the score down to a 2/5. What we do have is well written and entertaining for what it is. The new cast, setting, and idea for this crew are promising.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on June 17, 2022

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Well-written character driven sci-fi that will keep you up late into the night.
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I received an advance copy for review purposes and I enjoyed the book so much I also purchased it. Imperial Deserter kept me up exceedingly late two nights running. Few books have me reading till past 3am but this was one of them.Moriarty has crafted an excellent novel full of interesting and complex characters.  If you are a fan of Firefly you’ll find a lot to like here.  Part of the fun of the story is watching how the motley crew of characters who have been thrown together interact, with Dirk trying to ride herd and keep things from imploding (or exploding!).The writing is polished and every scene counts.  If you enjoyed Moriarty’s Trans Galatic Insurance (TGI) series you’ll likely appreciate this book as well, but it isn’t necessary to have read TGI first.  His first series is a little more light-hearted in style, but I still found myself chuckling out loud in parts of Imperial Deserter.The book works well as a satisfying stand-alone novel and we aren’t left with a cliff hanger but it is clear that there are more adventures to come.  The characters obviously have well developed back-stories and I’m looking forward to discovering more about their pasts as the series progresses.Buy this if you enjoy well-written character driven sci-fi with resourceful (but flawed) protagonists, trying to hold things together in the face of adversity.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on June 1, 2022

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Lots of fun, reminds me of Firefly
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Great Series.  I'm on Book 5 and having a great time.  This series reminds me a lot of Firefly - a group of misfits/criminals stuck on a ship together and need to do jobs flying around the edge of Imperial space to get by.  There's also a good long-term plot that has a nice slow build - and we get to find out why the characters are each "on the run" as we move through the books.  Adventure Awaits!

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Some parts of the book were exciting. Some parts were funny. Overall it was basically an alright book.My biggest hang up was the character of Dirk.According to the synopsis, this story was supposed to be about him. But it seemed that Dirk was just a minor character in the book. There was more adventures written about every other character. He was supposed to be the Captain and the command decisions he made were basically on the lines of “everyone should get along” and “let’s go there”.Other problems with the book that I had was the childish swearing and the fact that even though people had guns they never actually shot anyone, except in that one adventure on Dena’s planet. Even the Dirk character, who was supposed to be a quick draw never shot the thugs who came for Ana and Scruggs.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: This is a Very Good Read = I discovered a new author to read!
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Very fun book! :) A space opera with lots of fun humor and situations. The introduction and process of revealing the characters and their quirks is fun and entertaining. The historical situation of the empire does fit the known patterns of history related to empires and dynasties. It is neat reading a story set in the environment of this type of historical environment with such interesting characters. This is a book that kept me reflecting on the action and characters at all times of the day and night when I was not able to continue to read to find out what happens next. As you likely guessed, this novel has lots of action and adventure. The sequel has just arrived and I can't wait to see what happens next. I very highly recommend this book!

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: Sound start to a new series

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: The guilty flee when EVERYONE pursues
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: I love how this initial book in a new series sets the scene for what could well be a series with legs.The author has placed a dispirate band of people on board a spaceship each with their own complementary skillset for the crew of a spaceship and each with their own reasons to flee from too great an interest from officialdom - in at least three interstellar 'empires'.The author has great repartee going between his six main characters - initial contact between them is believable fractious but is slowly evolving to the point they are willingly working together while bits and pieces of their back stories are starting to be revealed. At the same time not everyone involved in their pursuit really wants to catch up with them.  It should make for future interesting interactions.Anyone who likes a storyline with flashes of humour and believable dialogue should find this book well worth reading. Personally I decided to buy the next book in series before I was 20% of the way through this one and look forward to reading more about their further adventures.

bookDescription:
When Earth's colonies go silent, Legion Varus drops onto Kepler-62 expecting a routine investigation. Instead, they find something far worse than death.
The colonists aren't dead—they're changed. A new kind of enemy has arrived in Province 921, microscopic invaders that transform humans into perfectly coordinated killing machines. These "Demon" parasites don't just control minds, they improve them, creating an army that works with terrifying efficiency.
As cities fall and soldiers turn against their own, Centurion James McGill discovers he's mysteriously immune to infection. But immunity comes with a price. To save humanity from becoming pawns of a new Galactic species, McGill must navigate a web of seduction, betrayal, and impossible choices.
Some invasions come with warships. Others come with a whisper, a touch, and a promise of something better. The question is: what happens when the enemy might be right?
DEMON WORLD is the latest action-packed entry in B.V. Larson's bestselling Undying Mercenaries series.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: James McGill is at it again.
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I've read all the books in the series. Actually, I've recently re-read the whole McGill saga.James is one of my favorite characters.He's larger than life and yet so down to earth relatable somehow. He's a horndog who can't stay away from the women. But he's also a brutal killer when it's necessary.  This story held my interest from beginning to end.  This story had a lot of unexpected twists and turnsto it. James was juggling family drama and galactic problems at the same time. Throw in an unusual love interest and  a lot of brutal fighting against impossible odds. Then you have the makings of a great story.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on August 26, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Who could think that Humanity's government would fire its lawyer and set a course of actions that will get the entire human race exterminated? That really seemed to be something obvious and avoidable; the pattern was always to make any infringement destroyable, renounceable, or deniable!This may not change everything, but it changes a lot. The new storyline offers a lot, and it's extremely unsettling.I do hope we get a cloud city, maybe suspended from a moon into a gas giant? There was a book written by an author who committed suicide because he thought he was a failure, because his publisher didn't tell him how well he was selling. I don't recall his name offhand, but his stories really were good, and Baen picked up rights to republish. I think he had one, about Earth sending indestructible robots to explore Jupiter, and Jupiter's native species deciding on peace because it. I think a nod to that could work really well with the big guy!

bookDescription: How do you tell your part in the biggest tale in history?I ask because it's what I have to do. I'm Zoe Boutin Perry: A colonist stranded on a deadly pioneer world. Holy icon to a race of aliens. A player (and a pawn) in a interstellar chess match to save humanity, or to see it fall. Witness to history. Friend. Daughter. Human. Seventeen years old.Everyone on Earth knows the tale I am part of. But you don't know my tale: How I did what I did — how I did what I had to do — not just to stay alive but to keep you alive, too. All of you. I'm going to tell it to you now, the only way I know how: not straight but true, the whole thing, to try make you feel what I felt: the joy and terror and uncertainty, panic and wonder, despair and hope. Everything that happened, bringing us to Earth, and Earth out of its captivity. All through my eyes.It's a story you know. But you don't know it all.Old Man's War Series #1 Old Man’s War #2 The Ghost Brigades #3 The Last Colony #4 Zoe’s Tale #5 The Human Division #6 The End of All Things  Short fiction: “After the Coup” Other Tor Books The Android’s Dream Agent to the Stars Your Hate Mail Will Be Graded Fuzzy Nation Redshirts Lock In The Collapsing Empire (forthcoming)At the Publisher's request, this title is being sold without Digital Rights Management Software (DRM) applied.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I'm writing the same review for all of the John Scalzi books that I've read. If you want to know what this book's about, read the description and the sample. I'd only be repeating that info here. What I want you to know is that Scalzi is a genius Writer (with a capital "W"). "Writer" seems so pedestrian when referring to Scalzi. Better to describe him as "Novelist" or "Storyteller" or "Wordmonger" (maybe not that last one). Or "Craftsman." His stories are clever and brilliant, all unique, humorous and dramatic, believable...yet out there. If you want to get your mind off your troubles, or the troubles of the world, or you want to let go of your disbeliefs willingly (like a movie), or you need some frivolity, or you like plot twists and turns, or you think you can guess what's coming next or later in a story (like I do) but you get it totally wrong, or you just want a tale that blows your mind, read one of John Scalzi's books. I guarantee that you will be totally ecstatic, if not downright jubilant. You're welcome.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Satisfying Completion to The Last Colony
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Much of this book is a repetition of the original story in The Last Colony. Since you may already know that, I will attempt to avoid more disclosures that could be spoilers. While you many know the past, you start right away seeing things from her perspective. She is a teenage girl right out of 1960's Iowa, pure and simple, living in idyllic Huckleberry. How she became that girl is glossed over, as it is in previous works. One would expect a more cautious and wary personality from what we know of her.Here she is. You learn the backstory first. This young girl has some reason to be jaded or suffering from a sense of victimhood, but is happy and well adjusted to life with her odd parents. Dad is an ancient American, but not as ancient by a few hundred years as he needs to be for this story. Formerly a modern warrior himself he would be capable of wiping out the entire colony personally. Her mom is an artificially created human who sprang full grown into life as an elite warrior, capable of laying low entire Seal teams and dad. How does Scalzi make them loving and caring parents modeled from the days of Leave It To Beaver? I don't know. He sort of slips into it in his previous books, but it makes sense in Scalzi's Old Man's War series is as curious a blend of political corruption and idealism triumphant as you would ever read and believe. These people belong in that universe as he pulls that off again. They all must be from Iowa. And the two alien bodyguards? Bodyguards who would easily kill everyone she knows, including her mother, to keep her from any harm and are the representatives of a powerful alien race that worships her. The threat of displeasing her keeps them in line, barely. Now, you may wonder how any adventure could come to a girl surrounded by such an array as this. You don't know teenage girls.From a teenage girl's point of view of her life on the Last Colony of Roanoke you have: intelligent and dangerous pet alien monsters, slobbery dog, benign neglectful parents with just the right touch of mature wisdom, boys, girls, boys and girls again, politics, an alien planet complete with more aliens, and one other revered meta, keeping important secrets from the adults. You have to love that last one, from Tom Sawyer to Harry Potter, untold secrets are where the drama is.There's a story for you. Yet you still believe she is just your average middle class 1960's midwestern American girl with an iPad.She is immediately thrust into an adventure from her agraian life right into the rigors of colonizing an alien planet. Typical of a teenage girl, she discovers the terrible secret of the the mission before her parents, the leaders of the colony. Not by much, but a coup none the less that begins the story of how she and her friends are working their way to the same conclusion of the story as her parents and the rest of the colonists. The story is about her, her female and male friends and how life with the powerless develops parallel to the powers-that-be. She eventually becomes the story and the proud progeny of her parents. Although she's not, really. You may not notice that until you think about it.She is believable to me in the context of the story, There are some jerks and stops as the story gets started, but then Scalzi has to make this work and he does.Zoe is sort of like a midwestern Podkayne. The similarities between the two jumped out at me as I started this book. Not that the stories are anything alike other than teenage girl heroines written by male writers. But I think she is the teenage girl men who like women think of, when they are not designing killer aliens and enhanced humans with neat hardware to deal with them.Definitely worth the read and completes The Lost Colony nicely.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Well done different viewpoint of the events of “The Last Colony”
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I listened to the “The Last Colony” when it first came out.I really enjoyed it, but I was skeptical about this book. The same story, but from the teenage daughter’s (Zoe‘s) point of view? The author admits that this  book was in part intended for high school libraries. I didn’t think much of the idea of teenage romances, etc.But I was wrong. This book is excellent. It provides additional details and a whole new perspective. I really enjoyed it.

bookDescription: The final enemy has been revealed, and it's more insidious than Van could ever imagine, spanning space and time with the patience of immortality—and an utter disregard for all forms of life.On the run and broken, the Equal Grasp faces elimination on earth and everywhere else, their leader gone, their mission a shambles, and with new agents of justice hard on their heels.But the fight isn't over. In fact, it's just begun, and Van knows that every decision he's made for the past decade will come to bear on who lives, and who dies—And who is meant to rule over a universe where freedom and justice are the ultimate pursuit. At any cost, Van and his crew will finish the job, but they're going to need a lot of help from people and beings who have been observers.Until now.The time for watching is over. The time for victory is now. But the cost might be more than anyone can pay, and Van is no longer merely an agent of justice. He's a father, a husband, and a friend—and he's going to need every connection in the stars to defeat the ultimate enemy and save his people.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I love the characters in this book. They’re not just human and the aliens are all very unique.  All of them have very discerning personalities which just get better with each book. Above all, I love their banter, their humor, their witty one liners and arguments like sibling kids. The crew, with its family atmosphere, just continues to grow, thrive and surprise us with some of the most random things, like movie productions. There’s a lot going on in this crew’s life. They’re being pulled in many directions. The biggest threats being Calamity and the ever present traitorous Guild leaders and those who follow them—either,believing their bogus propaganda or they’re true believers in the abuse of power and are willing participants in that endeavor. The story seems to hop around a lot but that just cements the rather random chaos this crew and their Allie’s are fighting. A bold move at the end will either help them them or doom them.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Two years or so ago, when I first picked up this series I had no idea what an investment in time it was going to be! Especially when I got all caught up and had to wait for the next new book.And here I am, again, waiting for the next volume. Thanks ok, lots to read in the meantime!24 was pretty good. Lots of action, world building and interesting developments. My only complaint is that it took the entire book just to reach the ultimate step of what we knew was going to happen. And when i5 did it was an anti-climax. After all that happened Van and his band of merry sentients are not any closer to their actual goal.To end on a positive note I appreciate how Van is able to listen to his friends and let them help him make honorable, ethical decisions. It’s almost like a video game and we are given choices. All of which will advance the plot, but not all of which give the “A+” ending.I’m glad I picked this series up all those months ago.  Time well spent!Cheers!

And don't leave any cheese laying around😏

bookDescription:
Only Omega can free humanity.
When the Ornu came, they took Earth in a single night. Humanity never stood a chance. Now, they force us to crew their ships and fight their wars for them. They hold Earth hostage, and if we refuse to do their bidding, they’ll lay waste to our precious blue marble. Slaughtering the billions who live there.
But when Captain Bill Henderson is sent to claim a small moon for his masters, he finds something they never accounted for. An ancient warship – a behemoth abandoned for millennia by a species that reached its peak at the dawn of the universe.
Could this ship of ages be exactly what humanity needs to cast off the shackles of their oppressors? Find out in Book 1 of Starship Omega, an engrossing new military science fiction saga from bestselling authors Scott Bartlett and Joshua James.
