productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Author needs to figure out how his FTL works
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Really bracing read with amazing characters and tension that is through the roof.  That said, this author needs to figure out how his FTL works, it's completely skipped over.  There's some reference to fuel, some to teleporting, no one mentions how any of this works.  There's refueling stations, different stages of techonology, boarding vessels, none of the thrust or anything else is figured out it's all just thrown at you.  Really took me out of it.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2024

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Good sci-fi, clean language, good characters
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: If you like science fiction with interesting characters and a good plot, I recommend this series. The characters are believable, though flawed (but not too flawed) humans and the “bad guys” ( the Ornu) are totally disgusting but also believable. I appreciate the technology presented and it inspires my imagination. I also like that they don’t use crude language and I can recommend this series to my friends without having to issue an “R rating” disclaimer. I’ve read both books now and preordered the third in the series, Infinite Warship due out next year (please hurry!).
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: The book does not have an ending.  There are also a number of things not done, e.g., why wasn't Val asked if he could fix the Kettering whatever?  What was Val anyway? He sure was a stick-in-the-mud snot.  If he were the authors' idea of a moral conscience, I see him failing by not acknowledging certain moral dilemmas.  With most of these space battle stories, the idea of logistics is never addressed. In this book we at least get a little lip service as we acknowledge that food is in short supply, but then we load a bunch of refugees,  we acknowledge the weapons are finite, but fire 50 missiles at a time.  What the heck?  The story moves along with good character development of captain Bill, Al & Biria, but the rest not so good.  They are all survivors of the defeat of earth, and are now slave labor on a space ship under the supervision of their conquerors who control by the threat of exploding a device implanted in their chest.  They all dream of freedom, but know that rebellion would result in their death.  That is, until they're sent on an exercise to board a gigantic derelict left behind by an ancient race called primevals. It turns out to be sentient, and it decides to side with the humans supporting their wish to be free.  So then things get interesting as we follow the various problems the humans get into along with their frustratingly incomplete solutions.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on May 17, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: “The Forever Ship” follows in an established tradition of sentient spacecraft, and is a quick read. It’s kind of a literary snack food - a little salty, pungent in spots, but not exactly filling. It feels like Henry, the major character, gets short shrift through most of this story, and the unfolding story of the captain and his issues takes up too much space. Mostly it feels as if a good editor would really help this story. Doubt if I will read any more of this series.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Humanity has been conquered by the Onru, a serpent like race that uses the races they conquer to wage their wars. Captain Bill Henderson is trying to keep his crew together while maintaining peaceful relations with the on ship Onru monitor. Any misstep could result in his death at the hands of the twitchy, onboard, monitor, Nonus.A mysterious message from a long dead race has been received by the communications officer of the ship. The Onru are always on the lookout for tech from this race; tech that they can twist into some form of weapon to keep their vassal races subject to them. This time the tech turns out to be a lost starship controlled by an onboard AI. The Onru are exited over the find but soon find themselves at the mercy of their human vassals which are the only ones the AI will communicate with.If he plays his cards right, Captain Henderson has before him the potential to turn the tables on the Onru. The ship AI is not open to just any request from Henderson so progress is slow. Henderson has to make the ship AI happy while keeping the Onru believing he is doing his best to follow their orders. The Onru quickly become frustrated with Henderson’s efforts and begin threatening him with death if he doesn’tprovide results. Our story takes off at this point with plot twists and turns as Henderson tries to work with the ship AI to save humanity and still keep the Onru satisfied long enough for his plans to come to fruition.This is a great read. I highly recommend it and am looking forward very much to the next novel in the trilogy.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2024

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: Not a bad story. But I think you may be selling humanity short. Or, possibly, giving humanity too much credit. There should be more rebels. Even with the risks.Pacing gets bogged down occasionally and the multiple person perspectives can get confusing.Also the bad guys verge on the YA trope of monolithic evil, though that might be explained by them being aliens. Couple other YA tropes intrude as well, which is unfortunate.Can’t say more without spoilers but I would be interested in seeing what the author does to resolve some of the issues that came up in this book. I do worry, somewhat, about how some of these issues will be resolved because … spoilers.Disliked losing a couple characters, it is war and some die, but it was the ones I likedFive stars because writing is not easy and the technical aspects were well done. Edited well without jarring errors that can ruin other books.My opinion on style is just that, an opinion.

to Humanity being slaves in a hopeless situation and getting an unforeseen chance to be free.However, the price of freedom and a better future is high, both personaly and humanity itself.We know from the description of the book that the discovery of an ancient and powerful ship will be key.What I did'nt like was that it took almost a third of the book to get to the point where the ship and the human crew finally came together. I can understand that the authors found it fitting in order to gave the characters more background.For me, that was taking too long.However, once our crew got the ship - or should I say, the ship got the crew? , for that ship sure isn't showing all its cards -, then the story is one of it's kind and marvellously done.There is lots of action, very well-written and captivating. There are hard choices to be made, which made the plot fascinating at many points. Omega's actions and evaluations on some protagonists' decisions are letting you guess on his motives, which made for an Intriguing plot, indeed.Some main characters choices were captivating to witness.So, all in all, a splendid, very interesting plot. Five stars earned.However, almost one year to wait for the second book - how did that happen?!!

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Just finished this one the other day and am looking forward to the next book in the series. Interesting story with nicely developed characters. There are various sub-plots woven in, typically with each chapter told from the point of view of one character, and multiple timelines (although this is not a time travel tale). This broke up the reading in a way that kept me engaged and wanting to know what happens next. There is a very broad range of situations and events that put the characters and their principles to the test. Funny parts, too. There is a lot of heart in these stories. Recommended.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ Gillies has done it again! Reach for the Galaxy is the sequel to Return to the Galaxy, and is even better. Through memory recordings of people who lived through it, we learn more galactic history. In Return, Velal was a space cruiser captain at the beginning of the mutiny of the alien Ranid, a reptilian species which had been part of the Foundation 250 years. The Ranids’ plan is the genocide of all humans. Now Velal is a fleet admiral, responsible for millions of refugees.In Return, Ewan Scott partnered with an avatar, Jera, to prepare Earth to defend against the Ranid, who are on their way. In Reach to the Galaxy, more people join Ewan in this effort, and some are excited to explore the neighborhood (our solar system). Ewan’s plan to prepare Earth technologically faces challenges.Like Return, this ebook appears to be professionally edited; I noticed only one typo. Some people might be offended by some characters’ personal relationships and their sexual behavior. However, while sex is part of the story, it is never explicit but behind closed doors.Also, Reach for the Galaxy ends with a cliffhanger. Frankly, I despise them, but even Heinlein wrote an occasional cliffhanger, and I have to admit, this ending is incredibly effective. I am SO eager to read the next book! The problem is waiting for it; I’m not known for my patience. 😊 (Yes, I still believe Gillies will reach Heinlein’s stature someday.)Even if I removed a star because of the cliffhanger, Reach is so good, by rights it would have plenty to spare. You know, ten so extra stars. Unfortunately, I can’t give it that many stars (Amazon can be so unreasonable!) 🙂  so I give Reach to the Galaxy by BA Gillies ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️.BookloverJuly 30 2025

bookDescription:
The time has come to take the fight to the Lankies.
Mars has been under Lanky control for more than a year. Since then, the depleted forces of Earth’s alliances have rebuilt their fleets, staffing old warships with freshly trained troops. Torn between the need to beat the Lankies to the punch and taking enough time to put together an effective fighting force, command has decided to strike now.
Once again, seasoned veterans Andrew and Halley find themselves in charge of green troops and at the sharp tip of the spear as the combined military might of Earth goes up against the Lankies. But if there’s one constant in war, it’s that no battle plan survives first contact with the enemy…and the Lankies want to hold on to Mars as badly as humanity wants to reclaim it.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I have really enjoyed each of Marko Kloos' Frontlines books. Not only are they well written, but he tells a good story- not always easy in military science-fiction. When an author chooses to write in a first-person narrative style, often they fall victim to the old trope of "telling, instead of showing." I never feel that way in this series- like life, the story evolves in an "organic" fashion, and makes for a very enjoyable read. Like his other books, this one is full of Easter eggs and sly little winks to his audience, which always brought a grin to my face as I was reading- and I'm sure there are more I didn't catch.If I have one complaint- it's an oft-heard one; these books are WAY TOO SHORT! :) I tear through them in a few hours, so they can feel like a novella more than a full novel. In fact, as I have done for Books 2-4, I will probably re-read the series in order over the next day or two.I really like this world, the story and this writing style, and I hope we don't have to wait a year for the next one!
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2017

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: The fifth book in the Frontlines series, Fields of Fire drops us immediately into Humanity's big push to eradicate the Lanky threat at Earth's doorstep.Much of the novel is spent in the build-up to assaulting Mars, the current stronghold of the alien Lankies within the solar system. Again Marko Kloos leans on his real-world combat experience to deliver a great novel that honestly only has a few flaws.Mr. Kloos once again expands the world of Frontlines by bringing in new human factions, most notably the Eurocorps, the European Union's fighting force. Although small and previously unseen, Kloos manages to make this new faction interesting by showing their different route of approach to warfare as opposed to the North American Commonwealth and the SIno-Russian Alliance, the two largest factions in the series. It is easily the highlight of the novel, seeing this new injection of tech and fighting blood as the clock ticks closer to zero hour for the assault on Mars. And some intriguing turn of events shed new light on the still highly alien Lankies, giving them slightly more depth as we begin to see how their technology functions, and that they are more than just plodding proto-dinosaur aliens that simply charge blindly into the bullets of the main characters.However, as thrilling as the combat sequences are, I felt that Mr. Kloos spent far too much time focusing on locations that, while they forward the story, seem rather boring and somewhat clumsy. The sequence in Greenland, for example, very much comes off as an attempt to write horror and it stumbles more often than it succeeds. Another flaw is that Mr. Kloos increasingly over-sells the romantic sub-plot between the main character and his wife Halley. There's one thrilling moment in the romantic plot, however, and I found that singular moment almost more enjoyable than the rest of the novel put together.Once again Mr. Kloos's characterizations and descriptions are massively improved over the first two novels of the series, but he drags his heels somewhat and there's more than a little filler before the main event. However when the Battle for Mars kicks off, it's hard to turn your eyes away. Mr. Kloos simply needs to work on refining the romantic sub-plot to being less tedious. Again and I mean no offense by it, the romance between Grayson and Halley just feels like a mirror or a podium that Mr. Kloos can climb up on and say how much he loves his actual wife. It just got pretty tiresome.All in all, another excellent read with a few flaws that hold what honestly feels like a series book-end back.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on July 26, 2018

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Kloos Delivers Again in "Fields of Fire"
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: One of the best novels I've read this year and THE most consistent, high-quality military sci-fi series around, IMHO.If you're new to this series, I'd recommend NOT starting with this one. But if you've read any of the prior works, you need this book now.Kloos takes so many conventions of the genre and subtly turns them on their ear. Yes, the pace is exceptionally tense - the action graphic and fast - the descriptions of military hardware exacting and precise. But he does something relatively rare in the field.He makes the reader genuinely care about the protagonist. Not just the immediate goals of surviving the next engagement with the enemy, but his life, his dreams, his friends and his wife.Kloos is a veteran himself and makes use of that knowledge through his words, not in the context of traditional military science matters; but rather the mundane "Jarhead" type of descriptions. What a mess hall is like, how it feels to be on call 24 x 7, navigating the organization to get things done. It is these little nuggets of authenticity which don't move the plot forward, but breathe life into the pages which make the series for me.And I do have to admit that the final few pages of the novel were the most tension-filled of ANY novel I've read in recent years.Simply put, another top shelf offering from a great writer.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on March 11, 2017

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Best yet in a great series!
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I thought quite highly of Marko Kloos "Frontlines" series, calling it the best of ground-based mil sci-fi.  Somehow, the fifth book in the series raised the bar even further!.  It's Earth against the Lankies in Greenland and on Mars, so for setting alone it is worth reading.  But it is not a homogenous "Terran" force but one made up of Americans like Lt. Grayson and his wife Halley and also Russians and a variety of Europeans; Chinese are fighting the Lankies, too, but out of our sight.  Their equipment is advanced but understandable, and Mr. Kloos stays very true to the limitations of the soldiers' arms and armor.The gigantic Lankies are some of the best and most "alien" foes in the genre.  We never truly understand them, though the range of their capabilities become a bit more evident in this book.  They have taken Mars, trapping our settlers in a number of large bunkers while the Lanky version of terraforming is done.  Clearly, a Lanky presence there cannot be allowed to remain, so the stakes are never in doubt.  The drop ships and SI troopers are needed, but the task is one that may be too much.Finally, the writing is first rate and some of it, particularly at home in Liberty Falls, rises above the genre.  A pleasure to read!
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on April 8, 2017

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: La calidad no decae en este quinto libro, al contrario
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: A estas alturas de la serie, ya no cabe duda que Kloos me tiene más que ganado, pero es que incluso con todo lo que ha pasado en los anteriores libros, el autor sigue dando más.
